Section.Text: In respect of an offence that requires the prosecution to prove fault — other than negligence — an organization is a party to the offence if, with the intent at least in part to benefit the organization, one of its senior officers

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: acting within the scope of their authority, is a party to the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: having the mental state required to be a party to the offence and acting within the scope of their authority, directs the work of other representatives of the organization so that they do the act or make the omission specified in the offence; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: knowing that a representative of the organization is or is about to be a party to the offence, does not take all reasonable measures to stop them from being a party to the offence.

Subsection.Text: An accessory after the fact to an offence is one who, knowing that a person has been a party to the offence, receives, comforts or assists that person for the purpose of enabling that person to escape.

Section.MarginalNote: Where one party cannot be convicted
Section.Text: For greater certainty, sections 21 to 23 apply in respect of an accused notwithstanding the fact that the person whom the accused aids or abets, counsels or procures or receives, comforts or assists cannot be convicted of the offence.

Subsection.Text: Every one who, having an intent to commit an offence, does or omits to do anything for the purpose of carrying out the intention is guilty of an attempt to commit the offence whether or not it was possible under the circumstances to commit the offence.

The question whether an act or omission by a person who has an intent to commit an offence is or is not mere preparation to commit the offence, and too remote to constitute an attempt to commit the offence, is a question of law.

Heading.TitleText: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law

Section.MarginalNote: Protection of persons acting under authority

Subsection.Text: Every one who is required or authorized by law to do anything in the administration or enforcement of the law

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as a private person,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as a peace officer or public officer,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in aid of a peace officer or public officer, or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: by virtue of his office,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is, if he acts on reasonable grounds, justified in doing what he is required or authorized to do and in using as much force as is necessary for that purpose.

Subsection.Text: Where a person is required or authorized by law to execute a process or to carry out a sentence, that person or any person who assists him is, if that person acts in good faith, justified in executing the process or in carrying out the sentence notwithstanding that the process or sentence is defective or that it was issued or imposed without jurisdiction or in excess of jurisdiction.

Subject to subsections (4) and (5), a person is not justified for the purposes of subsection (1) in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm unless the person believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary for the self-preservation of the person or the preservation of any one under that person’s protection from death or grievous bodily harm.
A peace officer, and every person lawfully assisting the peace officer, is justified in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm to a person to be arrested, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the peace officer is proceeding lawfully to arrest, with or without warrant, the person to be arrested;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the offence for which the person is to be arrested is one for which that person may be arrested without warrant;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person to be arrested takes flight to avoid arrest;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the peace officer or other person using the force believes on reasonable grounds that the force is necessary for the purpose of protecting the peace officer, the person lawfully assisting the peace officer or any other person from imminent or future death or grievous bodily harm; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the flight cannot be prevented by reasonable means in a less violent manner.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Power in case of escape from penitentiary
Subsection.Text: A peace officer is justified in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm against an inmate who is escaping from a penitentiary within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the peace officer believes on reasonable grounds that any of the inmates of the penitentiary poses a threat of death or grievous bodily harm to the peace officer or any other person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the escape cannot be prevented by reasonable means in a less violent manner.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this section and sections 25.2 to 25.4.

Definition.Text: competent authority means, with respect to a public officer or a senior official,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, personally;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a member of a police service constituted under the laws of a province, the Minister responsible for policing in the province, personally; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of any other public officer or senior official, the Minister who has responsibility for the Act of Parliament that the officer or official has the power to enforce, personally.

Definition.Text: public officer means a peace officer, or a public officer who has the powers of a peace officer under an Act of Parliament.
senior official means a senior official who is responsible for law enforcement and who is designated under subsection (5).

Subsection.Text: It is in the public interest to ensure that public officers may effectively carry out their law enforcement duties in accordance with the rule of law and, to that end, to expressly recognize in law a justification for public officers and other persons acting at their direction to commit acts or omissions that would otherwise constitute offences.
A competent authority may designate public officers for the purposes of this section and sections 25.2 to 25.4.

A competent authority referred to in paragraph (a) or (b) of the definition of that term in subsection (1) may not designate any public officer under subsection (3) unless there is a public authority composed of persons who are not peace officers that may review the public officer’s conduct.

The Governor in Council or the lieutenant governor in council of a province, as the case may be, may designate a person or body as a public authority for the purposes of subsection (3.1), and that designation is conclusive evidence that the person or body is a public authority described in that subsection.

The competent authority shall make designations under subsection (3) on the advice of a senior official and shall consider the nature of the duties performed by the public officer in relation to law enforcement generally, rather than in relation to any particular investigation or enforcement activity.
A competent authority may designate senior officials for the purposes of this section and sections 25.2 to 25.4.
A senior official may designate a public officer for the purposes of this section and sections 25.2 to 25.4 for a period of not more than 48 hours if the senior official is of the opinion that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by reason of exigent circumstances, it is not feasible for the competent authority to designate a public officer under subsection (3); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the circumstances of the case, the public officer would be justified in committing an act or omission that would otherwise constitute an offence.

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: The senior official shall without delay notify the competent authority of the designation.

Subsection.Text: A designation under subsection (3) or (6) may be made subject to conditions, including conditions limiting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the duration of the designation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the conduct in the investigation of which a public officer may be justified in committing, or directing another person to commit, acts or omissions that would otherwise constitute an offence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the acts or omissions that would otherwise constitute an offence and that a public officer may be justified in committing or directing another person to commit.

Subsection.Text: A public officer is justified in committing an act or omission — or in directing the commission of an act or omission under subsection (10) — that would otherwise constitute an offence if the public officer

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is engaged in the investigation of an offence under, or the enforcement of, an Act of Parliament or in the investigation of criminal activity;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is designated under subsection (3) or (6); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: believes on reasonable grounds that the commission of the act or omission, as compared to the nature of the offence or criminal activity being investigated, is reasonable and proportional in the circumstances, having regard to such matters as the nature of the act or omission, the nature of the investigation and the reasonable availability of other means for carrying out the public officer’s law enforcement duties.

Subsection.Text: No public officer is justified in committing an act or omission that would otherwise constitute an offence and that would be likely to result in loss of or serious damage to property, or in directing the commission of an act or omission under subsection (10), unless, in addition to meeting the conditions set out in paragraphs (8)(a) to (c), he or she

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is personally authorized in writing to commit the act or omission — or direct its commission — by a senior official who believes on reasonable grounds that committing the act or omission, as compared to the nature of the offence or criminal activity being investigated, is reasonable and proportional in the circumstances, having regard to such matters as the nature of the act or omission, the nature of the investigation and the reasonable availability of other means for carrying out the public officer’s law enforcement duties; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: believes on reasonable grounds that the grounds for obtaining an authorization under paragraph (a) exist but it is not feasible in the circumstances to obtain the authorization and that the act or omission is necessary to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: preserve the life or safety of any person,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: prevent the compromise of the identity of a public officer acting in an undercover capacity, of a confidential informant or of a person acting covertly under the direction and control of a public officer, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: prevent the imminent loss or destruction of evidence of an indictable offence.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Person acting at direction of public officer
Subsection.Text: A person who commits an act or omission that would otherwise constitute an offence is justified in committing it if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a public officer directs him or her to commit that act or omission and the person believes on reasonable grounds that the public officer has the authority to give that direction; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: he or she believes on reasonable grounds that the commission of that act or omission is for the purpose of assisting the public officer in the public officer’s law enforcement duties.

Subsection.Text: Nothing in this section justifies

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the intentional or criminally negligent causing of death or bodily harm to another person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the wilful attempt in any manner to obstruct, pervert or defeat the course of justice; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conduct that would violate the sexual integrity of an individual.

Subsection.Text: Nothing in this section affects the protection, defences and immunities of peace officers and other persons recognized under the law of Canada.
Nothing in this section relieves a public officer of criminal liability for failing to comply with any other requirements that govern the collection of evidence.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception: offences under Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Subsection.Text: Nothing in this section justifies a public officer or a person acting at his or her direction in committing an act or omission — or a public officer in directing the commission of an act or omission — that constitutes an offence under a provision of Part I of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act or of the regulations made under it.

Section.Text: Every public officer who commits an act or omission — or directs the commission by another person of an act or omission — under paragraph 25.1(9)(a) or (b) shall, as soon as is feasible after the commission of the act or omission, file a written report with the appropriate senior official describing the act or omission.

Subsection.Text: Every competent authority shall publish or otherwise make available to the public an annual report for the previous year that includes, in respect of public officers and senior officials designated by the competent authority,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the number of designations made under subsection 25.1(6) by the senior officials;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of authorizations made under paragraph 25.1(9)(a) by the senior officials;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of times that acts and omissions were committed in accordance with paragraph 25.1(9)(b) by the public officers;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the conduct being investigated when the designations referred to in paragraph (a) or the authorizations referred to in paragraph (b) were made or when the acts or omissions referred to in paragraph (c) were committed; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the acts or omissions committed under the designations referred to in paragraph (a), under the authorizations referred to in paragraph (b) and in the manner described in paragraph (c).

Subsection.Text: The annual report shall not contain any information the disclosure of which would

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: compromise or hinder an ongoing investigation of an offence under an Act of Parliament;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: compromise the identity of a public officer acting in an undercover capacity, of a confidential informant or of a person acting covertly under the direction and control of a public officer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: endanger the life or safety of any person;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: prejudice a legal proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: otherwise be contrary to the public interest.

Subsection.Text: When a public officer commits an act or omission — or directs the commission by another person of an act or omission — under paragraph 25.1(9)(a) or (b), the senior official with whom the public officer files a written report under section 25.2 shall, as soon as is feasible after the report is filed, and no later than one year after the commission of the act or omission, notify in writing any person whose property was lost or seriously damaged as a result of the act or omission.
The competent authority may authorize the senior official not to notify the person under subsection (1) until the competent authority is of the opinion that notification would not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: compromise or hinder an ongoing investigation of an offence under an Act of Parliament;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: compromise the identity of a public officer acting in an undercover capacity, of a confidential informant or of a person acting covertly under the direction and control of a public officer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: endanger the life or safety of any person;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: prejudice a legal proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: otherwise be contrary to the public interest.

Section.Text: Every one who is authorized by law to use force is criminally responsible for any excess thereof according to the nature and quality of the act that constitutes the excess.

Section.MarginalNote: Use of force to prevent commission of offence
Section.Text: Every one is justified in using as much force as is reasonably necessary

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to prevent the commission of an offence

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for which, if it were committed, the person who committed it might be arrested without warrant, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: that would be likely to cause immediate and serious injury to the person or property of anyone; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to prevent anything being done that, on reasonable grounds, he believes would, if it were done, be an offence mentioned in paragraph (a).

Section.MarginalNote: Use of force on board an aircraft

Subsection.Text: Every person on an aircraft in flight is justified in using as much force as is reasonably necessary to prevent the commission of an offence against this Act or another Act of Parliament that the person believes on reasonable grounds, if it were committed, would be likely to cause immediate and serious injury to the aircraft or to any person or property therein.

This section applies in respect of any aircraft in flight in Canadian airspace and in respect of any aircraft registered in Canada in accordance with the regulations made under the Aeronautics Act in flight outside Canadian airspace.

Where a person who is authorized to execute a warrant to arrest believes, in good faith and on reasonable grounds, that the person whom he arrests is the person named in the warrant, he is protected from criminal responsibility in respect thereof to the same extent as if that person were the person named in the warrant.
Where a person is authorized to execute a warrant to arrest,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every one who, being called on to assist him, believes that the person in whose arrest he is called on to assist is the person named in the warrant, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every keeper of a prison who is required to receive and detain a person who he believes has been arrested under the warrant,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is protected from criminal responsibility in respect thereof to the same extent as if that person were the person named in the warrant.

Subsection.Text: It is the duty of every one who executes a process or warrant to have it with him, where it is feasible to do so, and to produce it when requested to do so.
It is the duty of every one who arrests a person, whether with or without a warrant, to give notice to that person, where it is feasible to do so, of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the process or warrant under which he makes the arrest; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reason for the arrest.

Subsection.Text: Failure to comply with subsection (1) or (2) does not of itself deprive a person who executes a process or warrant, or a person who makes an arrest, or those who assist them, of protection from criminal responsibility.

Section.Text: Every one who witnesses a breach of the peace is justified in interfering to prevent the continuance or renewal thereof and may detain any person who commits or is about to join in or to renew the breach of the peace, for the purpose of giving him into the custody of a peace officer, if he uses no more force than is reasonably necessary to prevent the continuance or renewal of the breach of the peace or than is reasonably proportioned to the danger to be apprehended from the continuance or renewal of the breach of the peace.

Subsection.Text: Every peace officer who witnesses a breach of the peace and every one who lawfully assists the peace officer is justified in arresting any person whom he finds committing the breach of the peace or who, on reasonable grounds, he believes is about to join in or renew the breach of the peace.

Every peace officer is justified in receiving into custody any person who is given into his charge as having been a party to a breach of the peace by one who has, or who on reasonable grounds the peace officer believes has, witnessed the breach of the peace.

Section.MarginalNote: Use of force to suppress riot

Subsection.Text: Every peace officer is justified in using or in ordering the use of as much force as the peace officer believes, in good faith and on reasonable grounds,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is necessary to suppress a riot; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is not excessive, having regard to the danger to be apprehended from the continuance of the riot.

Subsection.Text: Every one who is bound by military law to obey the command of his superior officer is justified in obeying any command given by his superior officer for the suppression of a riot unless the order is manifestly unlawful.
Every one is justified in obeying an order of a peace officer to use force to suppress a riot if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: he acts in good faith; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the order is not manifestly unlawful.

Subsection.Text: Every one who, in good faith and on reasonable grounds, believes that serious mischief will result from a riot before it is possible to secure the attendance of a peace officer is justified in using as much force as he believes in good faith and on reasonable grounds,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is necessary to suppress the riot; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is not excessive, having regard to the danger to be apprehended from the continuance of the riot.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, the question whether an order is manifestly unlawful or not is a question of law.

Section.MarginalNote: Duty of officers if rioters do not disperse

Subsection.Text: Where the proclamation referred to in section 67 has been made or an offence against paragraph 68(a) or (b) has been committed, it is the duty of a peace officer and of a person who is lawfully required by him to assist, to disperse or to arrest persons who do not comply with the proclamation.

No civil or criminal proceedings lie against a peace officer or a person who is lawfully required by a peace officer to assist him in respect of any death or injury that by reason of resistance is caused as a result of the performance by the peace officer or that person of a duty that is imposed by subsection (1).
Nothing in this section limits or affects any powers, duties or functions that are conferred or imposed by this Act with respect to the suppression of riots.

It is not a defence to an offence referred to in subsection (3) that the accused, by reason of self-induced intoxication, lacked the general intent or the voluntariness required to commit the offence, where the accused departed markedly from the standard of care as described in subsection (2).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Criminal fault by reason of intoxication
Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, a person departs markedly from the standard of reasonable care generally recognized in Canadian society and is thereby criminally at fault where the person, while in a state of self-induced intoxication that renders the person unaware of, or incapable of consciously controlling, their behaviour, voluntarily or involuntarily interferes or threatens to interfere with the bodily integrity of another person.

This section applies in respect of an offence under this Act or any other Act of Parliament that includes as an element an assault or any other interference or threat of interference by a person with the bodily integrity of another person.

Section.MarginalNote: Defence — use or threat of force

Subsection.Text: A person is not guilty of an offence if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they believe on reasonable grounds that force is being used against them or another person or that a threat of force is being made against them or another person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the act that constitutes the offence is committed for the purpose of defending or protecting themselves or the other person from that use or threat of force; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances.

Subsection.Text: In determining whether the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances, the court shall consider the relevant circumstances of the person, the other parties and the act, including, but not limited to, the following factors:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the force or threat;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the extent to which the use of force was imminent and whether there were other means available to respond to the potential use of force;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s role in the incident;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether any party to the incident used or threatened to use a weapon;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the size, age, gender and physical capabilities of the parties to the incident;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the nature, duration and history of any relationship between the parties to the incident, including any prior use or threat of force and the nature of that force or threat;

Paragraph.Label: (f.1)
Paragraph.Text: any history of interaction or communication between the parties to the incident;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the nature and proportionality of the person’s response to the use or threat of force; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: whether the act committed was in response to a use or threat of force that the person knew was lawful.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply if the force is used or threatened by another person for the purpose of doing something that they are required or authorized by law to do in the administration or enforcement of the law, unless the person who commits the act that constitutes the offence believes on reasonable grounds that the other person is acting unlawfully.
A person is not guilty of an offence if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they either believe on reasonable grounds that they are in peaceable possession of property or are acting under the authority of, or lawfully assisting, a person whom they believe on reasonable grounds is in peaceable possession of property;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: they believe on reasonable grounds that another person

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is about to enter, is entering or has entered the property without being entitled by law to do so,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is about to take the property, is doing so or has just done so, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is about to damage or destroy the property, or make it inoperative, or is doing so;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the act that constitutes the offence is committed for the purpose of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: preventing the other person from entering the property, or removing that person from the property, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: preventing the other person from taking, damaging or destroying the property or from making it inoperative, or retaking the property from that person; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply if the person who believes on reasonable grounds that they are, or who is believed on reasonable grounds to be, in peaceable possession of the property does not have a claim of right to it and the other person is entitled to its possession by law.

Subsection (1) does not apply if the other person is doing something that they are required or authorized by law to do in the administration or enforcement of the law, unless the person who commits the act that constitutes the offence believes on reasonable grounds that the other person is acting unlawfully.

Section.Text: Every schoolteacher, parent or person standing in the place of a parent is justified in using force by way of correction toward a pupil or child, as the case may be, who is under his care, if the force does not exceed what is reasonable under the circumstances.
Every one is protected from criminal responsibility for performing a surgical operation on any person for the benefit of that person if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the operation is performed with reasonable care and skill; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is reasonable to perform the operation, having regard to the state of health of the person at the time the operation is performed and to all the circumstances of the case.

Heading.TitleText: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person

Subsection.Text: Every one commits high treason who, in Canada,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: kills or attempts to kill Her Majesty, or does her any bodily harm tending to death or destruction, maims or wounds her, or imprisons or restrains her;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: levies war against Canada or does any act preparatory thereto; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: assists an enemy at war with Canada, or any armed forces against whom Canadian Forces are engaged in hostilities, whether or not a state of war exists between Canada and the country whose forces they are.

Subsection.Text: Every one commits treason who, in Canada,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: uses force or violence for the purpose of overthrowing the government of Canada or a province;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: without lawful authority, communicates or makes available to an agent of a state other than Canada, military or scientific information or any sketch, plan, model, article, note or document of a military or scientific character that he knows or ought to know may be used by that state for a purpose prejudicial to the safety or defence of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conspires with any person to commit high treason or to do anything mentioned in paragraph (a);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: forms an intention to do anything that is high treason or that is mentioned in paragraph (a) and manifests that intention by an overt act; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: conspires with any person to do anything mentioned in paragraph (b) or forms an intention to do anything mentioned in paragraph (b) and manifests that intention by an overt act.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsection (1) or (2), a Canadian citizen or a person who owes allegiance to Her Majesty in right of Canada,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: commits high treason if, while in or out of Canada, he does anything mentioned in subsection (1); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: commits treason if, while in or out of Canada, he does anything mentioned in subsection (2).

Subsection.Text: Where it is treason to conspire with any person, the act of conspiring is an overt act of treason.
Every one who commits high treason is guilty of an indictable offence and shall be sentenced to imprisonment for life.
Every one who commits treason is guilty of an indictable offence and liable

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to be sentenced to imprisonment for life if he is guilty of an offence under paragraph 46(2)(a), (c) or (d);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to be sentenced to imprisonment for life if he is guilty of an offence under paragraph 46(2)(b) or (e) committed while a state of war exists between Canada and another country; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to be sentenced to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years if he is guilty of an offence under paragraph 46(2)(b) or (e) committed while no state of war exists between Canada and another country.

Subsection.Text: No person shall be convicted of high treason or treason on the evidence of only one witness, unless the evidence of that witness is corroborated in a material particular by evidence that implicates the accused.
For the purposes of Part XXIII, the sentence of imprisonment for life prescribed by subsection (1) is a minimum punishment.
No proceedings for an offence of treason as defined by paragraph 46(2)(a) shall be commenced more than three years after the time when the offence is alleged to have been committed.
No proceedings shall be commenced under section 47 in respect of an overt act of treason expressed or declared by open and considered speech unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an information setting out the overt act and the words by which it was expressed or declared is laid under oath before a justice within six days after the time when the words are alleged to have been spoken; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a warrant for the arrest of the accused is issued within ten days after the time when the information is laid.

Section.MarginalNote: Acts intended to alarm Her Majesty or break public peace
Section.Text: Every one who wilfully, in the presence of Her Majesty,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: does an act with intent to alarm Her Majesty or to break the public peace, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: does an act that is intended or is likely to cause bodily harm to Her Majesty,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Section.MarginalNote: Assisting alien enemy to leave Canada, or omitting to prevent treason

Subsection.Text: Every one commits an offence who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: incites or wilfully assists a subject of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a state that is at war with Canada, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a state against whose forces Canadian Forces are engaged in hostilities, whether or not a state of war exists between Canada and the state whose forces they are,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: to leave Canada without the consent of the Crown, unless the accused establishes that assistance to the state referred to in subparagraph (i) or the forces of the state referred to in subparagraph (ii), as the case may be, was not intended thereby; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: knowing that a person is about to commit high treason or treason does not, with all reasonable dispatch, inform a justice of the peace or other peace officer thereof or make other reasonable efforts to prevent that person from committing high treason or treason.

Subsection.Text: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Section.Text: Every one who does an act of violence in order to intimidate Parliament or the legislature of a province is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Subsection.Text: Every one who does a prohibited act for a purpose prejudicial to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the safety, security or defence of Canada, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the safety or security of the naval, army or air forces of any state other than Canada that are lawfully present in Canada,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years.

Subsection.Text: In this section, prohibited act means an act or omission that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: impairs the efficiency or impedes the working of any vessel, vehicle, aircraft, machinery, apparatus or other thing; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: causes property, by whomever it may be owned, to be lost, damaged or destroyed.

Subsection.Text: No person does a prohibited act within the meaning of this section by reason only that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: he stops work as a result of the failure of his employer and himself to agree on any matter relating to his employment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: he stops work as a result of the failure of his employer and a bargaining agent acting on his behalf to agree on any matter relating to his employment; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: he stops work as a result of his taking part in a combination of workmen or employees for their own reasonable protection as workmen or employees.

Subsection.Text: No person does a prohibited act within the meaning of this section by reason only that he attends at or near or approaches a dwelling-house or place for the purpose only of obtaining or communicating information.

Section.Text: Every one who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: attempts, for a traitorous or mutinous purpose, to seduce a member of the Canadian Forces from his duty and allegiance to Her Majesty, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: attempts to incite or to induce a member of the Canadian Forces to commit a traitorous or mutinous act,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Section.Text: Every one who aids, assists, harbours or conceals a person who he knows is a deserter or absentee without leave from the Canadian Forces is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction, but no proceedings shall be instituted under this section without the consent of the Attorney General of Canada.

In proceedings for an offence against any provision in section 47 or sections 49 to 53, no evidence is admissible of an overt act unless that overt act is set out in the indictment or unless the evidence is otherwise relevant as tending to prove an overt act that is set out therein.

Section.MarginalNote: Offences in relation to members of R.C.M.P.
Section.Text: Every one who wilfully

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: persuades or counsels a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to desert or absent himself without leave,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: aids, assists, harbours or conceals a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police who he knows is a deserter or absentee without leave, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aids or assists a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to desert or absent himself without leave, knowing that the member is about to desert or absent himself without leave,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

Subsection.Text: Every person commits an offence who, without lawful excuse, procures to be made, possesses, transfers, sells or offers for sale an identity document that relates or purports to relate, in whole or in part, to another person.
For greater certainty, subsection (1) does not prohibit an act that is carried out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in good faith, in the ordinary course of the person’s business or employment or in the exercise of the duties of their office;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for genealogical purposes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: with the consent of the person to whom the identity document relates or of a person authorized to consent on behalf of the person to whom the document relates, or of the entity that issued the identity document; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for a legitimate purpose related to the administration of justice.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, identity document means a Social Insurance Number card, a driver’s licence, a health insurance card, a birth certificate, a death certificate, a passport as defined in subsection 57(5), a document that simplifies the process of entry into Canada, a certificate of citizenship, a document indicating immigration status in Canada, a certificate of Indian status or an employee identity card that bears the employee’s photograph and signature, or any similar document, issued or purported to be issued by a department or agency of the federal government or of a provincial or foreign government.
Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

Section.MarginalNote: Forgery of or uttering forged passport

Subsection.Text: Every one who, while in or out of Canada,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: forges a passport, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: knowing that a passport is forged

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: uses, deals with or acts on it, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: causes or attempts to cause any person to use, deal with or act on it, as if the passport were genuine,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Subsection.MarginalNote: False statement in relation to passport
Subsection.Text: Every one who, while in or out of Canada, for the purpose of procuring a passport for himself or any other person or for the purpose of procuring any material alteration or addition to any such passport, makes a written or an oral statement that he knows is false or misleading

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

Subsection.Text: Every one who without lawful excuse, the proof of which lies on him, has in his possession a forged passport or a passport in respect of which an offence under subsection (2) has been committed is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years.
For the purposes of proceedings under this section,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the place where a passport was forged is not material; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the definition false document in section 321, and section 366, apply with such modifications as the circumstances require.

Subsection.Text: In this section, passport has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Canadian Passport Order.

Where a person is alleged to have committed, while out of Canada, an offence under this section, proceedings in respect of that offence may, whether or not that person is in Canada, be commenced in any territorial division in Canada and the accused may be tried and punished in respect of that offence in the same manner as if the offence had been committed in that territorial division.
For greater certainty, the provisions of this Act relating to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: requirements that an accused appear at and be present during proceedings, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the exceptions to those requirements,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: apply to proceedings commenced in any territorial division pursuant to subsection (6).

Section.MarginalNote: Fraudulent use of certificate of citizenship

Subsection.Text: Every one who, while in or out of Canada,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: uses a certificate of citizenship or a certificate of naturalization for a fraudulent purpose, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: being a person to whom a certificate of citizenship or a certificate of naturalization has been granted, knowingly parts with the possession of that certificate with intent that it should be used for a fraudulent purpose,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Definition of certificate of citizenship and certificate of naturalization
Subsection.Text: In this section, certificate of citizenship and certificate of naturalization, respectively, mean a certificate of citizenship and a certificate of naturalization as defined by the Citizenship Act.
Seditious words are words that express a seditious intention.
A seditious libel is a libel that expresses a seditious intention.
A seditious conspiracy is an agreement between two or more persons to carry out a seditious intention.
Without limiting the generality of the meaning of the expression “seditious intention”, every one shall be presumed to have a seditious intention who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: teaches or advocates, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: publishes or circulates any writing that advocates,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the use, without the authority of law, of force as a means of accomplishing a governmental change within Canada.

Section.Text: Notwithstanding subsection 59(4), no person shall be deemed to have a seditious intention by reason only that he intends, in good faith,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to show that Her Majesty has been misled or mistaken in her measures;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to point out errors or defects in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the government or constitution of Canada or a province,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: Parliament or the legislature of a province, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the administration of justice in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to procure, by lawful means, the alteration of any matter of government in Canada; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: to point out, for the purpose of removal, matters that produce or tend to produce feelings of hostility and ill-will between different classes of persons in Canada.

Section.Text: Every one who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: speaks seditious words,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: publishes a seditious libel, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is a party to a seditious conspiracy,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Section.MarginalNote: Offences in relation to military forces

Subsection.Text: Every one who wilfully

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: interferes with, impairs or influences the loyalty or discipline of a member of a force,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: publishes, edits, issues, circulates or distributes a writing that advises, counsels or urges insubordination, disloyalty, mutiny or refusal of duty by a member of a force, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: advises, counsels, urges or in any manner causes insubordination, disloyalty, mutiny or refusal of duty by a member of a force,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Definition of member of a force
Subsection.Text: In this section, member of a force means a member of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Canadian Forces; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the naval, army or air forces of a state other than Canada that are lawfully present in Canada.

Subsection.Text: An unlawful assembly is an assembly of three or more persons who, with intent to carry out any common purpose, assemble in such a manner or so conduct themselves when they are assembled as to cause persons in the neighbourhood of the assembly to fear, on reasonable grounds, that they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: will disturb the peace tumultuously; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: will by that assembly needlessly and without reasonable cause provoke other persons to disturb the peace tumultuously.

Subsection.Text: Persons who are lawfully assembled may become an unlawful assembly if they conduct themselves with a common purpose in a manner that would have made the assembly unlawful if they had assembled in that manner for that purpose.

Persons are not unlawfully assembled by reason only that they are assembled to protect the dwelling-house of any one of them against persons who are threatening to break and enter it for the purpose of committing an indictable offence therein.

Section.Text: A riot is an unlawful assembly that has begun to disturb the peace tumultuously.

Subsection.Text: Every one who takes part in a riot is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years.

Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) while wearing a mask or other disguise to conceal their identity without lawful excuse is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 10 years.
Every one who is a member of an unlawful assembly is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.
Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) while wearing a mask or other disguise to conceal their identity without lawful excuse is guilty of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

Section.Text: A person who is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a justice, mayor or sheriff, or the lawful deputy of a mayor or sheriff,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a warden or deputy warden of a prison, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the institutional head of a penitentiary, as those expressions are defined in subsection 2(1) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act, or that person’s deputy,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: who receives notice that, at any place within the jurisdiction of the person, twelve or more persons are unlawfully and riotously assembled together shall go to that place and, after approaching as near as is safe, if the person is satisfied that a riot is in progress, shall command silence and thereupon make or cause to be made in a loud voice a proclamation in the following words or to the like effect:

Section.Oath: Her Majesty the Queen charges and commands all persons being assembled immediately to disperse and peaceably to depart to their habitations or to their lawful business on the pain of being guilty of an offence for which, on conviction, they may be sentenced to imprisonment for life. GOD SAVE THE QUEEN.

Section.Text: Every one is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: opposes, hinders or assaults, wilfully and with force, a person who begins to make or is about to begin to make or is making the proclamation referred to in section 67 so that it is not made;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: does not peaceably disperse and depart from a place where the proclamation referred to in section 67 is made within thirty minutes after it is made; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not depart from a place within thirty minutes when he has reasonable grounds to believe that the proclamation referred to in section 67 would have been made in that place if some person had not opposed, hindered or assaulted, wilfully and with force, a person who would have made it.

Section.Text: A peace officer who receives notice that there is a riot within his jurisdiction and, without reasonable excuse, fails to take all reasonable steps to suppress the riot is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may, by proclamation, make orders

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to prohibit assemblies, without lawful authority, of persons for the purpose

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: of training or drilling themselves,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: of being trained or drilled to the use of arms, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: of practising military exercises; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to prohibit persons when assembled for any purpose from training or drilling themselves or from being trained or drilled.

Subsection.Text: An order that is made under subsection (1) may be general or may be made applicable to particular places, districts or assemblies to be specified in the order.
Every one who contravenes an order made under this section is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years.

Section.Text: Every one who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: challenges or attempts by any means to provoke another person to fight a duel,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: attempts to provoke a person to challenge another person to fight a duel, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: accepts a challenge to fight a duel,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years.

Subsection.Text: A person commits forcible entry when that person enters real property that is in the actual and peaceable possession of another in a manner that is likely to cause a breach of the peace or reasonable apprehension of a breach of the peace.

For the purposes of subsection (1), it is immaterial whether or not a person is entitled to enter the real property or whether or not that person has any intention of taking possession of the real property.

A person commits forcible detainer when, being in actual possession of real property without colour of right, he detains it in a manner that is likely to cause a breach of the peace or reasonable apprehension of a breach of the peace, against a person who is entitled by law to possession of it.
The questions whether a person is in actual and peaceable possession or is in actual possession without colour of right are questions of law.

Section.Text: Every person who commits forcible entry or forcible detainer is guilty of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offence punishable on summary conviction; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years.

Subsection.Text: Every one commits piracy who does any act that, by the law of nations, is piracy.
Every one who commits piracy while in or out of Canada is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

Section.Text: Every one who, while in or out of Canada,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: steals a Canadian ship,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: steals or without lawful authority throws overboard, damages or destroys anything that is part of the cargo, supplies or fittings in a Canadian ship,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does or attempts to do a mutinous act on a Canadian ship, or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: counsels a person to do anything mentioned in paragraph (a), (b) or (c),

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Heading.TitleText: Offences against Air or Maritime Safety

Section.Text: Every one who, unlawfully, by force or threat thereof, or by any other form of intimidation, seizes or exercises control of an aircraft with intent

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to cause any person on board the aircraft to be confined or imprisoned against his will,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to cause any person on board the aircraft to be transported against his will to any place other than the next scheduled place of landing of the aircraft,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to hold any person on board the aircraft for ransom or to service against his will, or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: to cause the aircraft to deviate in a material respect from its flight plan,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

Section.MarginalNote: Endangering safety of aircraft or airport
Section.Text: Every one who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on board an aircraft in flight, commits an act of violence against a person that is likely to endanger the safety of the aircraft,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: using a weapon, commits an act of violence against a person at an airport serving international civil aviation that causes or is likely to cause serious injury or death and that endangers or is likely to endanger safety at the airport,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: causes damage to an aircraft in service that renders the aircraft incapable of flight or that is likely to endanger the safety of the aircraft in flight,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: places or causes to be placed on board an aircraft in service anything that is likely to cause damage to the aircraft, that will render it incapable of flight or that is likely to endanger the safety of the aircraft in flight,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: causes damage to or interferes with the operation of any air navigation facility where the damage or interference is likely to endanger the safety of an aircraft in flight,

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: using a weapon, substance or device, destroys or causes serious damage to the facilities of an airport serving international civil aviation or to any aircraft not in service located there, or causes disruption of services of the airport, that endangers or is likely to endanger safety at the airport, or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: endangers the safety of an aircraft in flight by communicating to any other person any information that the person knows to be false,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

Subsection.Text: Every one, other than a peace officer engaged in the execution of his duty, who takes on board a civil aircraft an offensive weapon or any explosive substance

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: without the consent of the owner or operator of the aircraft or of a person duly authorized by either of them to consent thereto, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with the consent referred to in paragraph (a) but without complying with all terms and conditions on which the consent was given,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, civil aircraft means all aircraft other than aircraft operated by the Canadian Forces, a police force in Canada or persons engaged in the administration or enforcement of the Customs Act, the Excise Act or the Excise Act, 2001.

Section.MarginalNote: Seizing control of ship or fixed platform

Subsection.Text: Every one who seizes or exercises control over a ship or fixed platform by force or threat of force or by any other form of intimidation is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Endangering safety of ship or fixed platform
Subsection.Text: Every one who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: commits an act of violence against a person on board a ship or fixed platform,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: destroys or causes damage to a ship or its cargo or to a fixed platform,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: destroys or causes serious damage to or interferes with the operation of any maritime navigational facility, or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: places or causes to be placed on board a ship or fixed platform anything that is likely to cause damage to the ship or its cargo or to the fixed platform,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: where that act is likely to endanger the safe navigation of a ship or the safety of a fixed platform, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

Subsection.Text: Every one who communicates information that endangers the safe navigation of a ship, knowing the information to be false, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

Every one who threatens to commit an offence under paragraph (2)(a), (b) or (c) in order to compel a person to do or refrain from doing any act, where the threat is likely to endanger the safe navigation of a ship or the safety of a fixed platform, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.
In this section,

Definition.Text: fixed platform means an artificial island or a marine installation or structure that is permanently attached to the seabed for the purpose of exploration or exploitation of resources or for other economic purposes;

ship means every description of vessel not permanently attached to the seabed, other than a warship, a ship being used as a naval auxiliary or for customs or police purposes or a ship that has been withdrawn from navigation or is laid up.

Section.Text: Every one who has an explosive substance in his possession or under his care or control is under a legal duty to use reasonable care to prevent bodily harm or death to persons or damage to property by that explosive substance.

Every one who, being under a legal duty within the meaning of section 79, fails without lawful excuse to perform that duty, is guilty of an indictable offence and, if as a result an explosion of an explosive substance occurs that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: causes death or is likely to cause death to any person, is liable to imprisonment for life; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: causes bodily harm or damage to property or is likely to cause bodily harm or damage to property, is liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Subsection.Text: Every one commits an offence who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: does anything with intent to cause an explosion of an explosive substance that is likely to cause serious bodily harm or death to persons or is likely to cause serious damage to property;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with intent to do bodily harm to any person

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: causes an explosive substance to explode,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: sends or delivers to a person or causes a person to take or receive an explosive substance or any other dangerous substance or thing, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: places or throws anywhere or at or on a person a corrosive fluid, explosive substance or any other dangerous substance or thing;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: with intent to destroy or damage property without lawful excuse, places or throws an explosive substance anywhere; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: makes or has in his possession or has under his care or control any explosive substance with intent thereby

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to endanger life or to cause serious damage to property, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to enable another person to endanger life or to cause serious damage to property.

Subsection.Text: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for an offence under paragraph (1)(a) or (b), to imprisonment for life; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for an offence under paragraph (1)(c) or (d), to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Subsection.Text: Every person who, without lawful excuse, the proof of which lies on the person, makes or has in the possession or under the care or control of the person any explosive substance is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Possession in association with criminal organization
Subsection.Text: Every person who, without lawful excuse, the proof of which lies on the person, makes or has in the possession or under the care or control of the person any explosive substance for the benefit of, at the direction of or in association with a criminal organization is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Section.Text: A sentence imposed on a person for an offence under subsection 82(2) shall be served consecutively to any other punishment imposed on the person for an offence arising out of the same event or series of events and to any other sentence to which the person is subject at the time the sentence is imposed on the person for an offence under subsection 82(2).
For the purposes of sections 82.3 to 82.5, device means any of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a nuclear explosive device;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a device that disperses radioactive material;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a device that emits ionizing radiation and that is capable of causing death, serious bodily harm or substantial damage to property or the environment.

Section.MarginalNote: Possession, etc., of nuclear material, radioactive material or device
Section.Text: Everyone who, with intent to cause death, serious bodily harm or substantial damage to property or the environment, makes a device or possesses, uses, transfers, exports, imports, alters or disposes of nuclear material, radioactive material or a device or commits an act against a nuclear facility or an act that causes serious interference with or serious disruption of its operations, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

Section.MarginalNote: Use or alteration of nuclear material, radioactive material or device
Section.Text: Everyone who, with intent to compel a person, government or international organization to do or refrain from doing any act, uses or alters nuclear material, radioactive material or a device or commits an act against a nuclear facility or an act that causes serious interference with or serious disruption of its operations, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

Section.MarginalNote: Commission of indictable offence to obtain nuclear material, etc.
Section.Text: Everyone who commits an indictable offence under this or any other Act of Parliament, with intent to obtain nuclear material, radioactive material or a device or to obtain access to a nuclear facility, is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for life.
Everyone who threatens to commit an offence under any of sections 82.3 to 82.5 is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years.

For greater certainty, sections 82.3 to 82.6 do not apply to an act that is committed during an armed conflict and that, at the time and in the place of its commission, is in accordance with customary international law or conventional international law applicable to the conflict, or to activities undertaken by military forces of a state in the exercise of their official duties, to the extent that those activities are governed by other rules of international law.

Subsection.Text: Every one who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: engages as a principal in a prize fight,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: advises, encourages or promotes a prize fight, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is present at a prize fight as an aid, second, surgeon, umpire, backer or reporter,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

Subsection.Text: In this section, prize fight means an encounter or fight with fists, hands or feet between two persons who have met for that purpose by previous arrangement made by or for them, but does not include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a contest between amateur athletes in a combative sport with fists, hands or feet held in a province if the sport is on the programme of the International Olympic Committee or the International Paralympic Committee and, in the case where the province’s lieutenant governor in council or any other person or body specified by him or her requires it, the contest is held with their permission;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a contest between amateur athletes in a combative sport with fists, hands or feet held in a province if the sport has been designated by the province’s lieutenant governor in council or by any other person or body specified by him or her and, in the case where the lieutenant governor in council or other specified person or body requires it, the contest is held with their permission;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a contest between amateur athletes in a combative sport with fists, hands or feet held in a province with the permission of the province’s lieutenant governor in council or any other person or body specified by him or her; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a boxing contest or mixed martial arts contest held in a province with the permission or under the authority of an athletic board, commission or similar body established by or under the authority of the province’s legislature for the control of sport within the province.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: Canadian means a Canadian citizen, a permanent resident within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act or a body corporate incorporated and continued under the laws of Canada or a province.
entity means a person, group, trust, partnership or fund or an unincorporated association or organization.
listed entity means an entity on a list established by the Governor in Council under section 83.05.
terrorist activity means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an act or omission that is committed in or outside Canada and that, if committed in Canada, is one of the following offences:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the offences referred to in subsection 7(2) that implement the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Seizure of Aircraft, signed at The Hague on December 16, 1970,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the offences referred to in subsection 7(2) that implement the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts against the Safety of Civil Aviation, signed at Montreal on September 23, 1971,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the offences referred to in subsection 7(3) that implement the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of Crimes against Internationally Protected Persons, including Diplomatic Agents, adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations on December 14, 1973,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the offences referred to in subsection 7(3.1) that implement the International Convention against the Taking of Hostages, adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations on December 17, 1979,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the offences referred to in subsection 7(2.21) that implement the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material, done at Vienna and New York on March 3, 1980, as amended by the Amendment to the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material, done at Vienna on July 8, 2005 and the International Convention for the Suppression of Acts of Nuclear Terrorism, done at New York on September 14, 2005,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the offences referred to in subsection 7(2) that implement the Protocol for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts of Violence at Airports Serving International Civil Aviation, supplementary to the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts against the Safety of Civil Aviation, signed at Montreal on February 24, 1988,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the offences referred to in subsection 7(2.1) that implement the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts against the Safety of Maritime Navigation, done at Rome on March 10, 1988,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: the offences referred to in subsection 7(2.1) or (2.2) that implement the Protocol for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts against the Safety of Fixed Platforms Located on the Continental Shelf, done at Rome on March 10, 1988,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: the offences referred to in subsection 7(3.72) that implement the International Convention for the Suppression of Terrorist Bombings, adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations on December 15, 1997, and

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: the offences referred to in subsection 7(3.73) that implement the International Convention for the Suppression of the Financing of Terrorism, adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations on December 9, 1999, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an act or omission, in or outside Canada,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that is committed

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: in whole or in part for a political, religious or ideological purpose, objective or cause, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: in whole or in part with the intention of intimidating the public, or a segment of the public, with regard to its security, including its economic security, or compelling a person, a government or a domestic or an international organization to do or to refrain from doing any act, whether the public or the person, government or organization is inside or outside Canada, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: that intentionally

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: causes death or serious bodily harm to a person by the use of violence,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: endangers a person’s life,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: causes a serious risk to the health or safety of the public or any segment of the public,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: causes substantial property damage, whether to public or private property, if causing such damage is likely to result in the conduct or harm referred to in any of clauses (A) to (C), or

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: causes serious interference with or serious disruption of an essential service, facility or system, whether public or private, other than as a result of advocacy, protest, dissent or stoppage of work that is not intended to result in the conduct or harm referred to in any of clauses (A) to (C),

ContinuedDefinition.Text: and includes a conspiracy, attempt or threat to commit any such act or omission, or being an accessory after the fact or counselling in relation to any such act or omission, but, for greater certainty, does not include an act or omission that is committed during an armed conflict and that, at the time and in the place of its commission, is in accordance with customary international law or conventional international law applicable to the conflict, or the activities undertaken by military forces of a state in the exercise of their official duties, to the extent that those activities are governed by other rules of international law.

Definition.Text: terrorist group means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an entity that has as one of its purposes or activities facilitating or carrying out any terrorist activity, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a listed entity,

ContinuedDefinition.Text: and includes an association of such entities.

Subsection.Text: For greater certainty, the expression of a political, religious or ideological thought, belief or opinion does not come within paragraph (b) of the definition “terrorist activity” in subsection (1) unless it constitutes an act or omission that satisfies the criteria of that paragraph.
For greater certainty, a suicide bombing is an act that comes within paragraph (a) or (b) of the definition terrorist activity in subsection (1) if it satisfies the criteria of that paragraph.
For the purposes of this Part, facilitation shall be construed in accordance with subsection 83.19(2).

Section.MarginalNote: Providing or collecting property for certain activities
Section.Text: Every one who, directly or indirectly, wilfully and without lawful justification or excuse, provides or collects property intending that it be used or knowing that it will be used, in whole or in part, in order to carry out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an act or omission that constitutes an offence referred to in subparagraphs (a)(i) to (ix) of the definition of terrorist activity in subsection 83.01(1), or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other act or omission intended to cause death or serious bodily harm to a civilian or to any other person not taking an active part in the hostilities in a situation of armed conflict, if the purpose of that act or omission, by its nature or context, is to intimidate the public, or to compel a government or an international organization to do or refrain from doing any act,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years.

Section.MarginalNote: Providing, making available, etc., property or services for terrorist purposes
Section.Text: Every one who, directly or indirectly, collects property, provides or invites a person to provide, or makes available property or financial or other related services

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: intending that they be used, or knowing that they will be used, in whole or in part, for the purpose of facilitating or carrying out any terrorist activity, or for the purpose of benefiting any person who is facilitating or carrying out such an activity, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: knowing that, in whole or part, they will be used by or will benefit a terrorist group,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years.

Section.MarginalNote: Using or possessing property for terrorist purposes
Section.Text: Every one who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: uses property, directly or indirectly, in whole or in part, for the purpose of facilitating or carrying out a terrorist activity, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: possesses property intending that it be used or knowing that it will be used, directly or indirectly, in whole or in part, for the purpose of facilitating or carrying out a terrorist activity,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may, by regulation, establish a list on which the Governor in Council may place any entity if, on the recommendation of the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, the Governor in Council is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the entity has knowingly carried out, attempted to carry out, participated in or facilitated a terrorist activity; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the entity is knowingly acting on behalf of, at the direction of or in association with an entity referred to in paragraph (a).
