Paragraph.Text: any application made in respect of the property under any of those provisions or any other provision of this or any other Act of Parliament that provides for the restoration or forfeiture of such property,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any appeal taken from an order of forfeiture or restoration in respect of the property, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other proceeding in which the right of seizure of the property is questioned,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and property shall not be disposed of within thirty days after an order of forfeiture is made under any of those provisions.

Section.MarginalNote: Copies of documents returned or forfeited

Subsection.Text: If any document is returned or ordered to be returned, forfeited or otherwise dealt with under subsection 462.34(3) or (4), 462.37(1) or (2.01), 462.38(2) or 462.41(3) or section 462.43, the Attorney General may, before returning the document or complying with the order, cause a copy of the document to be made and retained.

Every copy made under subsection (1) shall, if certified as a true copy by the Attorney General, be admissible in evidence and, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, shall have the same probative force as the original document would have had if it had been proved in the ordinary way.

Section.MarginalNote: No civil or criminal liability incurred by informants
Section.Text: For greater certainty but subject to section 241 of the Income Tax Act, a person is justified in disclosing to a peace officer or the Attorney General any facts on the basis of which that person reasonably suspects that any property is proceeds of crime or that any person has committed or is about to commit a designated offence.

Subsection.Text: In this section, designated substance offence means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under Part I of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, except subsection 4(1) of that Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a conspiracy or an attempt to commit, being an accessory after the fact in relation to, or any counselling in relation to, an offence referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: The Attorney General may make an application in accordance with subsection (2) for an order for disclosure of information under subsection (3), for the purposes of an investigation in relation to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a designated substance offence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an offence against section 354, 355.2, 355.4 or 462.31 if the offence is alleged to have been committed in relation to any property, thing or proceeds obtained or derived directly or indirectly as a result of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the commission in Canada of a designated substance offence, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an act or omission anywhere that, if it had occurred in Canada, would have constituted a designated substance offence;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an offence against section 467.11, 467.111, 467.12 or 467.13, or a conspiracy or an attempt to commit, or being an accessory after the fact in relation to, such an offence; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a terrorism offence.

Subsection.Text: An application under subsection (1.1) shall be made ex parte in writing to a judge and be accompanied by an affidavit sworn on the information and belief of the Attorney General or a person specially designated by the Attorney General for that purpose deposing to the following matters, namely,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the offence or matter under investigation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person in relation to whom the information or documents referred to in paragraph (c) are required;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the type of information or book, record, writing, return or other document obtained by or on behalf of the Minister of National Revenue for the purposes of the Income Tax Act to which access is sought or that is proposed to be examined or communicated; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the facts relied on to justify the belief, on reasonable grounds, that the person referred to in paragraph (b) has committed or benefited from the commission of any of the offences referred to in subsection (1.1) and that the information or documents referred to in paragraph (c) are likely to be of substantial value, whether alone or together with other material, to the investigation for the purposes of which the application is made.

Subsection.Text: Where the judge to whom an application under subsection (1.1) is made is satisfied

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: of the matters referred to in paragraph (2)(d), and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that there are reasonable grounds for believing that it is in the public interest to allow access to the information or documents to which the application relates, having regard to the benefit likely to accrue to the investigation if the access is obtained,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the judge may, subject to any conditions that the judge considers advisable in the public interest, order the Commissioner of Revenue or any person specially designated in writing by the Commissioner for the purposes of this section

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to allow a police officer named in the order access to all such information and documents and to examine them, or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the judge considers it necessary in the circumstances, to produce all such information and documents to the police officer and allow the police officer to remove the information and documents,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: within such period after the expiration of seven clear days following the service of the order pursuant to subsection (4) as the judge may specify.

Subsection.Text: A copy of an order made by a judge under subsection (3) shall be served on the person to whom the order is addressed in such manner as the judge directs or as may be prescribed by rules of court.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Extension of period for compliance with order
Subsection.Text: A judge who makes an order under subsection (3) may, on application of the Minister of National Revenue, extend the period within which the order is to be complied with.

The Minister of National Revenue or any person specially designated in writing by that Minister for the purposes of this section may object to the disclosure of any information or document in respect of which an order under subsection (3) has been made by certifying orally or in writing that the information or document should not be disclosed on the ground that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister of National Revenue is prohibited from disclosing the information or document by any bilateral or international treaty, convention or other agreement respecting taxation to which the Government of Canada is a signatory;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a privilege is attached by law to the information or document;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the information or document has been placed in a sealed package pursuant to law or an order of a court of competent jurisdiction; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: disclosure of the information or document would not, for any other reason, be in the public interest.

Subsection.Text: Where an objection to the disclosure of information or a document is made under subsection (6), the objection may be determined, on application, in accordance with subsection (8), by the Chief Justice of the Federal Court, or by such other judge of that Court as the Chief Justice may designate to hear such applications.

A judge who is to determine an objection pursuant to subsection (7) may, if the judge considers it necessary to determine the objection, examine the information or document in relation to which the objection is made and shall grant the objection and order that disclosure of the information or document be refused where the judge is satisfied of any of the grounds mentioned in subsection (6).

An application under subsection (7) shall be made within ten days after the objection is made or within such greater or lesser period as the Chief Justice of the Federal Court, or such other judge of that Court as the Chief Justice may designate to hear such applications, considers appropriate.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Appeal to Federal Court of Appeal
Subsection.Text: An appeal lies from a determination under subsection (7) to the Federal Court of Appeal.

An appeal under subsection (10) shall be brought within ten days from the date of the determination appealed from or within such further time as the Federal Court of Appeal considers appropriate in the circumstances.
An application under subsection (7) or an appeal brought in respect of that application shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be heard in camera; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the request of the person objecting to the disclosure of information, be heard and determined in the National Capital Region described in the schedule to the National Capital Act.

Subsection.Text: During the hearing of an application under subsection (7) or an appeal brought in respect of that application, the person who made the objection in respect of which the application was made or the appeal was brought shall, on the request of that person, be given the opportunity to make representations ex parte.

When any information or document is examined or provided under subsection (3), the person by whom it is examined or to whom it is provided or any officer of the Canada Revenue Agency may make, or cause to be made, one or more copies of it, and any copy purporting to be certified by the Minister of National Revenue or an authorized person to be a copy made under this subsection is evidence of the nature and content of the original information or document and has the same probative force as the original information or document would have had if it had been proved in the ordinary way.

No person to whom information or documents have been disclosed or provided pursuant to this subsection or pursuant to an order made under subsection (3) shall further disclose the information or documents except for the purposes of the investigation in relation to which the order was made.
An order made under subsection (3) may be in Form 47.
In this section, police officer means any officer, constable or other person employed for the preservation and maintenance of the public peace.

Section.MarginalNote: Specific forfeiture provisions unaffected by this Part

Subsection.Text: This Part does not affect the operation of any other provision of this or any other Act of Parliament respecting the forfeiture of property.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Priority for restitution to victims of crime
Subsection.Text: The property of an offender may be used to satisfy the operation of a provision of this or any other Act of Parliament respecting the forfeiture of property only to the extent that it is not required to satisfy the operation of any other provision of this or any other Act of Parliament respecting restitution to or compensation of persons affected by the commission of offences.

Section.Text: The Attorney General may make regulations governing the manner of disposing of or otherwise dealing with, in accordance with the law, property forfeited under this Part.
Except where otherwise expressly provided by law, the following provisions apply in respect of persons who attempt to commit or are accessories after the fact to the commission of offences:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every one who attempts to commit or is an accessory after the fact to the commission of an indictable offence for which, on conviction, an accused is liable to be sentenced to imprisonment for life is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every one who attempts to commit or is an accessory after the fact to the commission of an indictable offence for which, on conviction, an accused is liable to imprisonment for fourteen years or less is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term that is one-half of the longest term to which a person who is guilty of that offence is liable;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: every one who attempts to commit or is an accessory after the fact to the commission of an offence punishable on summary conviction is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: every one who attempts to commit or is an accessory after the fact to the commission of an offence for which the offender may be prosecuted by indictment or for which he is punishable on summary conviction

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding a term that is one-half of the longest term to which a person who is guilty of that offence is liable, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

Section.MarginalNote: Counselling offence that is not committed
Section.Text: Except where otherwise expressly provided by law, the following provisions apply in respect of persons who counsel other persons to commit offences, namely,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every one who counsels another person to commit an indictable offence is, if the offence is not committed, guilty of an indictable offence and liable to the same punishment to which a person who attempts to commit that offence is liable; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every one who counsels another person to commit an offence punishable on summary conviction is, if the offence is not committed, guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

Subsection.Text: Except where otherwise expressly provided by law, the following provisions apply in respect of conspiracy:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every one who conspires with any one to commit murder or to cause another person to be murdered, whether in Canada or not, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to a maximum term of imprisonment for life;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every one who conspires with any one to prosecute a person for an alleged offence, knowing that he did not commit that offence, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years, if the alleged offence is one for which, on conviction, that person would be liable to be sentenced to imprisonment for life or for a term not exceeding fourteen years, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years, if the alleged offence is one for which, on conviction, that person would be liable to imprisonment for less than fourteen years;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: every one who conspires with any one to commit an indictable offence not provided for in paragraph (a) or (b) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to the same punishment as that to which an accused who is guilty of that offence would, on conviction, be liable; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: every one who conspires with any one to commit an offence punishable on summary conviction is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

Subsection.Text: Every one who, while in Canada, conspires with any one to do anything referred to in subsection (1) in a place outside Canada that is an offence under the laws of that place shall be deemed to have conspired to do that thing in Canada.
Every one who, while in a place outside Canada, conspires with any one to do anything referred to in subsection (1) in Canada shall be deemed to have conspired in Canada to do that thing.

Where a person is alleged to have conspired to do anything that is an offence by virtue of subsection (3) or (4), proceedings in respect of that offence may, whether or not that person is in Canada, be commenced in any territorial division in Canada, and the accused may be tried and punished in respect of that offence in the same manner as if the offence had been committed in that territorial division.
For greater certainty, the provisions of this Act relating to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: requirements that an accused appear at and be present during proceedings, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the exceptions to those requirements,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: apply to proceedings commenced in any territorial division pursuant to subsection (5).

Subsection.Text: Where a person is alleged to have conspired to do anything that is an offence by virtue of subsection (3) or (4) and that person has been tried and dealt with outside Canada in respect of the offence in such a manner that, if the person had been tried and dealt with in Canada, he would be able to plead autrefois acquit, autrefois convict or pardon, the person shall be deemed to have been so tried and dealt with in Canada.
A conspiracy in restraint of trade is an agreement between two or more persons to do or to procure to be done any unlawful act in restraint of trade.
The purposes of a trade union are not, by reason only that they are in restraint of trade, unlawful within the meaning of subsection (1).
No person shall be convicted of the offence of conspiracy by reason only that he

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: refuses to work with a workman or for an employer; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: does any act or causes any act to be done for the purpose of a trade combination, unless that act is an offence expressly punishable by law.

Subsection.Text: In this section, trade combination means any combination between masters or workmen or other persons for the purpose of regulating or altering the relations between masters or workmen, or the conduct of a master or workman in or in respect of his business, employment or contract of employment or service.
The following definitions apply in this Act.

Definition.Text: criminal organization means a group, however organized, that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is composed of three or more persons in or outside Canada; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has as one of its main purposes or main activities the facilitation or commission of one or more serious offences that, if committed, would likely result in the direct or indirect receipt of a material benefit, including a financial benefit, by the group or by any of the persons who constitute the group.

ContinuedDefinition.Text: It does not include a group of persons that forms randomly for the immediate commission of a single offence.

Definition.Text: serious offence means an indictable offence under this or any other Act of Parliament for which the maximum punishment is imprisonment for five years or more, or another offence that is prescribed by regulation.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, section 467.11 and 467.111, facilitation of an offence does not require knowledge of a particular offence the commission of which is facilitated, or that an offence actually be committed.
In this section and in sections 467.11 to 467.13, committing an offence means being a party to it or counselling any person to be a party to it.
The Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing offences that are included in the definition “serious offence” in subsection (1).

Section.MarginalNote: Participation in activities of criminal organization

Subsection.Text: Every person who, for the purpose of enhancing the ability of a criminal organization to facilitate or commit an indictable offence under this or any other Act of Parliament, knowingly, by act or omission, participates in or contributes to any activity of the criminal organization is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years.
In a prosecution for an offence under subsection (1), it is not necessary for the prosecutor to prove that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the criminal organization actually facilitated or committed an indictable offence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the participation or contribution of the accused actually enhanced the ability of the criminal organization to facilitate or commit an indictable offence;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the accused knew the specific nature of any indictable offence that may have been facilitated or committed by the criminal organization; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the accused knew the identity of any of the persons who constitute the criminal organization.

Subsection.Text: In determining whether an accused participates in or contributes to any activity of a criminal organization, the Court may consider, among other factors, whether the accused

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: uses a name, word, symbol or other representation that identifies, or is associated with, the criminal organization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: frequently associates with any of the persons who constitute the criminal organization;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: receives any benefit from the criminal organization; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: repeatedly engages in activities at the instruction of any of the persons who constitute the criminal organization.

Section.MarginalNote: Recruitment of members by a criminal organization
Section.Text: Every person who, for the purpose of enhancing the ability of a criminal organization to facilitate or commit an indictable offence under this Act or any other Act of Parliament, recruits, solicits, encourages, coerces or invites a person to join the criminal organization, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case where the person recruited, solicited, encouraged or invited is under 18 years of age, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years, and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of six months; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years.

Section.MarginalNote: Commission of offence for criminal organization

Subsection.Text: Every person who commits an indictable offence under this or any other Act of Parliament for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

In a prosecution for an offence under subsection (1), it is not necessary for the prosecutor to prove that the accused knew the identity of any of the persons who constitute the criminal organization.

Section.MarginalNote: Instructing commission of offence for criminal organization

Subsection.Text: Every person who is one of the persons who constitute a criminal organization and who knowingly instructs, directly or indirectly, any person to commit an offence under this or any other Act of Parliament for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, the criminal organization is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.
In a prosecution for an offence under subsection (1), it is not necessary for the prosecutor to prove that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offence other than the offence under subsection (1) was actually committed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the accused instructed a particular person to commit an offence; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the accused knew the identity of all of the persons who constitute the criminal organization.

Section.Text: A sentence imposed on a person for an offence under section 467.11, 467.111, 467.12 or 467.13 shall be served consecutively to any other punishment imposed on the person for an offence arising out of the same event or series of events and to any other sentence to which the person is subject at the time the sentence is imposed on the person for an offence under any of those sections.

Section.MarginalNote: Powers of the Attorney General of Canada

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding the definition of “Attorney General” in section 2, the Attorney General of Canada may conduct proceedings in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under section 467.11 or 467.111; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: another criminal organization offence where the alleged offence arises out of conduct that in whole or in part is in relation to an alleged contravention of an Act of Parliament or a regulation made under such an Act, other than this Act or a regulation made under this Act.

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: For those purposes, the Attorney General of Canada may exercise all the powers and perform all the duties and functions assigned to the Attorney General by or under this Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Powers of the Attorney General of a province
Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not affect the authority of the Attorney General of a province to conduct proceedings in respect of an offence referred to in section 467.11, 467.111, 467.12 or 467.13 or to exercise any of the powers or perform any of the duties and functions assigned to the Attorney General by or under this Act.

Section.Text: Every superior court of criminal jurisdiction has jurisdiction to try any indictable offence.
Every court of criminal jurisdiction has jurisdiction to try an indictable offence other than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under any of the following sections:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 47 (treason),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 49 (alarming Her Majesty),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 51 (intimidating Parliament or a legislature),

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 53 (inciting to mutiny),

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: section 61 (seditious offences),

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: section 74 (piracy),

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 75 (piratical acts), or

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 235 (murder);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the offence of being an accessory after the fact to high treason or treason or murder;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under section 119 (bribery) by the holder of a judicial office;

Paragraph.Label: (c.1)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under any of sections 4 to 7 of the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the offence of attempting to commit any offence mentioned in subparagraphs (a)(i) to (vii); or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the offence of conspiring to commit any offence mentioned in paragraph (a).

Section.Text: Subject to this Act, every superior court of criminal jurisdiction and every court of criminal jurisdiction that has power to try an indictable offence is competent to try an accused for that offence

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the accused is found, is arrested or is in custody within the territorial jurisdiction of the court; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the accused has been ordered to be tried by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that court, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other court, the jurisdiction of which has by lawful authority been transferred to that court.

Section.Text: Except where otherwise expressly provided by law, every accused who is charged with an indictable offence shall be tried by a court composed of a judge and jury.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding anything in this Act, an accused charged with an offence listed in section 469 may, with the consent of the accused and the Attorney General, be tried without a jury by a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction.

Where the consent of the accused and the Attorney General is given in accordance with subsection (1), the judge of the superior court of criminal jurisdiction may order that any offence be tried by that judge in conjunction with the offence listed in section 469.

Notwithstanding anything in this Act, where the consent of an accused and the Attorney General is given in accordance with subsection (1), that consent shall not be withdrawn unless both the accused and the Attorney General agree to the withdrawal.

Where the competent authority has determined that a panel of jurors is not to be summoned for a term or sittings of the court for the trial of criminal cases in any territorial division, the clerk of the court may, on the day of the opening of the term or sittings, if a judge is not present to preside over the court, adjourn the court and the business of the court to a subsequent day.

A clerk of the court for the trial of criminal cases in any territorial division may, at any time, on the instructions of the presiding judge or another judge of the court, adjourn the court and the business of the court to a subsequent day.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, where an accused, whether or not he is charged jointly with another, absconds during the course of his trial,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: he shall be deemed to have waived his right to be present at his trial, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the court may

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: continue the trial and proceed to a judgment or verdict and, if it finds the accused guilty, impose a sentence on him in his absence, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if a warrant in Form 7 is issued for the arrest of the accused, adjourn the trial to await his appearance,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: but where the trial is adjourned pursuant to subparagraph (b)(ii), the court may, at any time, continue the trial if it is satisfied that it is no longer in the interests of justice to await the appearance of the accused.

Subsection.Text: Where a court continues a trial pursuant to subsection (1), it may draw an inference adverse to the accused from the fact that he has absconded.

Where an accused reappears at his trial that is continuing pursuant to subsection (1), he is not entitled to have any part of the proceedings that was conducted in his absence re-opened unless the court is satisfied that because of exceptional circumstances it is in the interests of justice to re-open the proceedings.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Counsel for accused may continue to act
Subsection.Text: Where an accused has absconded during the course of his trial and the court continues the trial, counsel for the accused is not thereby deprived of any authority he may have to continue to act for the accused in the proceedings.

Section.Text: For the purposes of this Act,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where an offence is committed in or on any water or on a bridge between two or more territorial divisions, the offence shall be deemed to have been committed in any of the territorial divisions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where an offence is committed on the boundary of two or more territorial divisions or within five hundred metres of any such boundary, or the offence was commenced within one territorial division and completed within another, the offence shall be deemed to have been committed in any of the territorial divisions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where an offence is committed in or on a vehicle employed in a journey, or on board a vessel employed on a navigable river, canal or inland water, the offence shall be deemed to have been committed in any territorial division through which the vehicle or vessel passed in the course of the journey or voyage on which the offence was committed, and where the center or other part of the road, or navigable river, canal or inland water on which the vehicle or vessel passed in the course of the journey or voyage is the boundary of two or more territorial divisions, the offence shall be deemed to have been committed in any of the territorial divisions;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where an offence is committed in an aircraft in the course of a flight of that aircraft, it shall be deemed to have been committed

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the territorial division in which the flight commenced,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in any territorial division over which the aircraft passed in the course of the flight, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the territorial division in which the flight ended; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where an offence is committed in respect of the mail in the course of its door-to-door delivery, the offence shall be deemed to have been committed in any territorial division through which the mail was carried on that delivery.

Subsection.Text: In sections 477.1 to 477.4, ship includes any description of vessel, boat or craft designed, used or capable of being used solely or partly for marine navigation, without regard to method or lack of propulsion.
Nothing in sections 477.1 to 477.4 limits the operation of any other Act of Parliament or the jurisdiction that a court may exercise apart from those sections.

Section.Text: Every person who commits an act or omission that, if it occurred in Canada, would be an offence under a federal law, within the meaning of section 2 of the Oceans Act, is deemed to have committed that act or omission in Canada if it is an act or omission

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the exclusive economic zone of Canada that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is committed by a person who is in the exclusive economic zone of Canada in connection with exploring or exploiting, conserving or managing the natural resources, whether living or non-living, of the exclusive economic zone of Canada, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is committed by or in relation to a person who is a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that is committed in a place in or above the continental shelf of Canada and that is an offence in that place by virtue of section 20 of the Oceans Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that is committed outside Canada on board or by means of a ship registered or licensed, or for which an identification number has been issued, pursuant to any Act of Parliament;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: that is committed outside Canada in the course of hot pursuit; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: that is committed outside the territory of any state by a Canadian citizen.

Section.MarginalNote: Consent of Attorney General of Canada

Subsection.Text: No proceedings in respect of an offence committed in or on the territorial sea of Canada shall be continued unless the consent of the Attorney General of Canada is obtained not later than eight days after the proceedings are commenced, if the accused is not a Canadian citizen and the offence is alleged to have been committed on board any ship registered outside Canada.
Subsection (1) does not apply to proceedings by way of summary conviction.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Consent of Attorney General of Canada
Subsection.Text: No proceedings in respect of which courts have jurisdiction by virtue only of paragraph 477.1(a) or (b) shall be continued unless the consent of the Attorney General of Canada is obtained not later than eight days after the proceedings are commenced, if the accused is not a Canadian citizen and the offence is alleged to have been committed on board any ship registered outside Canada.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Consent of Attorney General of Canada
Subsection.Text: No proceedings in respect of which courts have jurisdiction by virtue only of paragraph 477.1(d) or (e) shall be continued unless the consent of the Attorney General of Canada is obtained not later than eight days after the proceedings are commenced.
The consent of the Attorney General required by subsection (1), (2) or (3) must be filed with the clerk of the court in which the proceedings have been instituted.

Section.MarginalNote: Exercising powers of arrest, entry, etc.

Subsection.Text: Every power of arrest, entry, search or seizure or other power that could be exercised in Canada in respect of an act or omission referred to in section 477.1 may be exercised, in the circumstances referred to in that section,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the place or on board the ship or marine installation or structure, within the meaning of section 2 of the Oceans Act, where the act or omission occurred; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where hot pursuit has been commenced, at any place on the seas, other than a place that is part of the territorial sea of any other state.

Subsection.Text: A justice or judge in any territorial division in Canada has jurisdiction to authorize an arrest, entry, search or seizure or an investigation or other ancillary matter related to an offence

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: committed in or on the territorial sea of Canada or any area of the sea that forms part of the internal waters of Canada, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: referred to in section 477.1

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: in the same manner as if the offence had been committed in that territorial division.

Subsection.Text: Where an act or omission that is an offence by virtue only of section 477.1 is alleged to have been committed on board any ship registered outside Canada, the powers referred to in subsection (1) shall not be exercised outside Canada with respect to that act or omission without the consent of the Attorney General of Canada.
In proceedings in respect of an offence,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate referred to in subsection 23(1) of the Oceans Act, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate issued by or under the authority of the Minister of Foreign Affairs containing a statement that any geographical location specified in the certificate was, at any time material to the proceedings, in an area of a fishing zone of Canada that is not within the internal waters of Canada or the territorial sea of Canada or outside the territory of any state,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is conclusive proof of the truth of the statement without proof of the signature or official character of the person appearing to have issued the certificate.

Subsection.Text: A certificate referred to in subsection (3) is admissible in evidence in proceedings referred to in that subsection but its production cannot be compelled.

Section.MarginalNote: Offence committed entirely in one province

Subsection.Text: Subject to this Act, a court in a province shall not try an offence committed entirely in another province.

Every proprietor, publisher, editor or other person charged with the publication of a defamatory libel in a newspaper or with conspiracy to publish a defamatory libel in a newspaper shall be dealt with, indicted, tried and punished in the province where he resides or in which the newspaper is printed.

An accused who is charged with an offence that is alleged to have been committed in Canada outside the province in which the accused is may, if the offence is not an offence mentioned in section 469 and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of proceedings instituted at the instance of the Government of Canada and conducted by or on behalf of that Government, if the Attorney General of Canada consents, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, if the Attorney General of the province where the offence is alleged to have been committed consents,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: appear before a court or judge that would have had jurisdiction to try that offence if it had been committed in the province where the accused is, and where the accused consents to plead guilty and pleads guilty to that offence, the court or judge shall determine the accused to be guilty of the offence and impose the punishment warranted by law, but where the accused does not consent to plead guilty and does not plead guilty, the accused shall, if the accused was in custody prior to appearance, be returned to custody and shall be dealt with according to law.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Where accused ordered to stand trial
Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding that an accused described in subsection (3) has been ordered to stand trial or that an indictment has been preferred against the accused in respect of the offence to which he desires to plead guilty, the accused shall be deemed simply to stand charged of that offence without a preliminary inquiry having been conducted or an indictment having been preferred with respect thereto.
In this section, newspaper has the same meaning as in section 297.

Section.Text: Where an accused is charged with an offence that is alleged to have been committed in the province in which he is, he may, if the offence is not an offence mentioned in section 469 and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of proceedings instituted at the instance of the Government of Canada and conducted by or on behalf of that Government, the Attorney General of Canada consents, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, the Attorney General of the province where the offence is alleged to have been committed consents,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: appear before a court or judge that would have had jurisdiction to try that offence if it had been committed in the place where the accused is, and where the accused consents to plead guilty and pleads guilty to that offence, the court or judge shall determine the accused to be guilty of the offence and impose the punishment warranted by law, but where the accused does not consent to plead guilty and does not plead guilty, the accused shall, if the accused was in custody prior to appearance, be returned to custody and shall be dealt with according to law.

Subsection.Text: Where an offence is committed in an unorganized tract of country in any province or on a lake, river or other water therein, not included in a territorial division or in a provisional judicial district, proceedings in respect thereof may be commenced and an accused may be charged, tried and punished in respect thereof within any territorial division or provisional judicial district of the province in the same manner as if the offence had been committed within that territorial division or provisional judicial district.

Where a provisional judicial district or a new territorial division is constituted in an unorganized tract referred to in subsection (1), the jurisdiction conferred by that subsection continues until appropriate provision is made by law for the administration of criminal justice within the provisional judicial district or new territorial division.

Section.Text: Where an offence is committed in a part of Canada not in a province, proceedings in respect thereof may be commenced and the accused may be charged, tried and punished within any territorial division in any province in the same manner as if that offence had been committed in that territorial division.

Where an offence is committed in or on the territorial sea of Canada or any area of the sea that forms part of the internal waters of Canada, proceedings in respect thereof may, whether or not the accused is in Canada, be commenced and an accused may be charged, tried and punished within any territorial division in Canada in the same manner as if the offence had been committed in that territorial division.

Subject to this or any other Act of Parliament, where an act or omission is committed outside Canada and the act or omission is an offence when committed outside Canada under this or any other Act of Parliament, proceedings in respect of the offence may, whether or not the accused is in Canada, be commenced, and an accused may be charged, tried and punished within any territorial division in Canada in the same manner as if the offence had been committed in that territorial division.
For greater certainty, the provisions of this Act relating to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the requirement of the appearance of an accused at proceedings, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the exceptions to that requirement

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: apply to proceedings commenced in any territorial division pursuant to section 481, 481.1 or 481.2.

Subsection.Text: Every superior court of criminal jurisdiction and every court of appeal may make rules of court not inconsistent with this or any other Act of Parliament, and any rules so made apply to any prosecution, proceeding, action or appeal, as the case may be, within the jurisdiction of that court, instituted in relation to any matter of a criminal nature or arising from or incidental to any such prosecution, proceeding, action or appeal.

The following courts may, subject to the approval of the lieutenant governor in council of the relevant province, make rules of court not inconsistent with this Act or any other Act of Parliament that are applicable to any prosecution, proceeding, including a preliminary inquiry or proceedings within the meaning of Part XXVII, action or appeal, as the case may be, within the jurisdiction of that court, instituted in relation to any matter of a criminal nature or arising from or incidental to the prosecution, proceeding, action or appeal:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every court of criminal jurisdiction for a province;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every appeal court within the meaning of section 812 that is not a court referred to in subsection (1);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Ontario Court of Justice;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the Court of Quebec and every municipal court in the Province of Quebec;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the Provincial Court of Nova Scotia;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the Provincial Court of New Brunswick;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the Provincial Court of Manitoba;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the Provincial Court of British Columbia;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the Provincial Court of Prince Edward Island;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the Provincial Court of Saskatchewan;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the Provincial Court of Alberta;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the Provincial Court of Newfoundland and Labrador;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the Territorial Court of Yukon;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the Territorial Court of the Northwest Territories; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: the Nunavut Court of Justice.

Subsection.Text: Rules under subsection (1) or (2) may be made

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: generally to regulate the duties of the officers of the court and any other matter considered expedient to attain the ends of justice and carry into effect the provisions of the law;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to regulate the sittings of the court or any division thereof, or of any judge of the court sitting in chambers, except in so far as they are regulated by law;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to regulate the pleading, practice and procedure in criminal matters, including pre-hearing conferences held under section 625.1, proceedings with respect to judicial interim release and preliminary inquiries and, in the case of rules under subsection (1), proceedings with respect to mandamus, certiorari, habeas corpus, prohibition and procedendo and proceedings on an appeal under section 830; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: to carry out the provisions of this Act relating to appeals from conviction, acquittal or sentence and, without restricting the generality of this paragraph,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for furnishing necessary forms and instructions in relation to notices of appeal or applications for leave to appeal to officials or other persons requiring or demanding them,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for ensuring the accuracy of notes taken at a trial and the verification of any copy or transcript,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: for keeping writings, exhibits or other things connected with the proceedings on the trial,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: for securing the safe custody of property during the period in which the operation of an order with respect to that property is suspended under subsection 689(1), and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: for providing that the Attorney General and counsel who acted for the Attorney General at the trial be supplied with certified copies of writings, exhibits and things connected with the proceedings that are required for the purposes of their duties.

Subsection.Text: Rules of court that are made under the authority of this section shall be published in the Canada Gazette.

Notwithstanding anything in this section, the Governor in Council may make such provision as he considers proper to secure uniformity in the rules of court in criminal matters, and all uniform rules made under the authority of this subsection prevail and have effect as if enacted by this Act.

Section.MarginalNote: Power to make rules respecting case management

Subsection.Text: A court referred to in subsection 482(1) or (2) may make rules for case management, including rules

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the determination of any matter that would assist the court in effective and efficient case management;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: permitting personnel of the court to deal with administrative matters relating to proceedings out of court if the accused is represented by counsel; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: establishing case management schedules.

Subsection.Text: The parties to a case shall comply with any direction made in accordance with a rule made under subsection (1).
If rules are made under subsection (1), a court, justice or judge may issue a summons or warrant to compel the presence of the accused at case management proceedings.
Section 512 and subsection 524(1) apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, to the issuance of a summons or a warrant under subsection (3).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Approval of lieutenant governor in council
Subsection.Text: Rules made under this section by a court referred to in subsection 482(2) must be approved by the lieutenant governor in council of the relevant province in order to come into force.
Subsections 482(4) and (5) apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, to rules made under subsection (1).

Section.MarginalNote: Officials with powers of two justices
Section.Text: Every judge or provincial court judge authorized by the law of the province in which he is appointed to do anything that is required to be done by two or more justices may do alone anything that this Act or any other Act of Parliament authorizes two or more justices to do.

Every judge or provincial court judge has the same power and authority to preserve order in a court over which he presides as may be exercised by the superior court of criminal jurisdiction of the province during the sittings thereof.

Subsection.Text: Jurisdiction over an offence is not lost by reason of the failure of any court, judge, provincial court judge or justice to act in the exercise of that jurisdiction at any particular time, or by reason of a failure to comply with any of the provisions of this Act respecting adjournments or remands.

Jurisdiction over an accused is not lost by reason of the failure of the accused to appear personally, so long as subsection 515(2.2), paragraph 537(1)(j), (j.1) or (k), subsection 650(1.1) or (1.2), paragraph 650(2)(b) or 650.01(3)(a), subsection 683(2.1) or 688(2.1) or a rule of court made under section 482 or 482.1 applies.

Where jurisdiction over an accused or a defendant is lost and has not been regained, a court, judge, provincial court judge or justice may, within three months after the loss of jurisdiction, issue a summons, or if it or he considers it necessary in the public interest, a warrant for the arrest of the accused or defendant.

Where no summons or warrant is issued under subsection (2) within the period provided therein, the proceedings shall be deemed to be dismissed for want of prosecution and shall not be recommenced except in accordance with section 485.1.

Where, in the opinion of the court, judge, provincial court judge or justice, an accused or a defendant who appears at a proceeding has been misled or prejudiced by reason of any matter referred to in subsection (1), the court, judge, provincial court judge or justice may adjourn the proceeding and may make such order as it or he considers appropriate.
The provisions of Part XVI apply with such modifications as the circumstances require where a summons or warrant is issued under subsection (2).

Section.MarginalNote: Recommencement where dismissal for want of prosecution
Section.Text: Where an indictment in respect of a transaction is dismissed or deemed by any provision of this Act to be dismissed for want of prosecution, a new information shall not be laid and a new indictment shall not be preferred before any court in respect of the same transaction without

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the personal consent in writing of the Attorney General or Deputy Attorney General, in any prosecution conducted by the Attorney General or in which the Attorney General intervenes; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the written order of a judge of that court, in any prosecution conducted by a prosecutor other than the Attorney General and in which the Attorney General does not intervene.

Subsection.Text: Any proceedings against an accused shall be held in open court, but the presiding judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor or a witness or on his or her own motion, order the exclusion of all or any members of the public from the court room for all or part of the proceedings, or order that the witness testify behind a screen or other device that would allow the witness not to be seen by members of the public, if the judge or justice is of the opinion that such an order is in the interest of public morals, the maintenance of order or the proper administration of justice or is necessary to prevent injury to international relations or national defence or national security.

The application may be made, during the proceedings, to the presiding judge or justice or, before the proceedings begin, to the judge or justice who will preside at the proceedings or, if that judge or justice has not been determined, to any judge or justice having jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place.
In determining whether the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice, the judge or justice shall consider

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the safeguarding of the interests of witnesses under the age of 18 years in all proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the ability of the witness to give a full and candid account of the acts complained of if the order were not made;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether the witness needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the protection of justice system participants who are involved in the proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: whether effective alternatives to the making of the proposed order are available in the circumstances;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the salutary and deleterious effects of the proposed order; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

Subsection.Text: If an accused is charged with an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1, 155 or 159, subsection 160(2) or (3) or section 163.1, 170, 171, 171.1, 172, 172.1, 172.2, 173, 271, 272, 273, 279.01, 279.011, 279.02, 279.03, 286.1, 286.2 or 286.3 and the prosecutor or the accused applies for an order under subsection (1), the judge or justice shall, if no such order is made, state, by reference to the circumstances of the case, the reason for not making an order.
No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that an order is, or is not, made under this section.

Section.MarginalNote: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability

Subsection.Text: In any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice shall, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness who is under the age of 18 years or who has a mental or physical disability, or on application of such a witness, order that a support person of the witness’ choice be permitted to be present and to be close to the witness while the witness testifies, unless the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order would interfere with the proper administration of justice.

In any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness, or on application of a witness, order that a support person of the witness’ choice be permitted to be present and to be close to the witness while the witness testifies if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order would facilitate the giving of a full and candid account by the witness of the acts complained of or would otherwise be in the interest of the proper administration of justice.

An application referred to in subsection (1) or (2) may be made, during the proceedings, to the presiding judge or justice or, before the proceedings begin, to the judge or justice who will preside at the proceedings or, if that judge or justice has not been determined, to any judge or justice having jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place.
In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the age of the witness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the witness’ mental or physical disabilities, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of any relationship between the witness and the accused;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether the witness needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Witness not to be a support person
Subsection.Text: The judge or justice shall not permit a witness to be a support person unless the judge or justice is of the opinion that doing so is necessary for the proper administration of justice.
The judge or justice may order that the support person and the witness not communicate with each other while the witness testifies.
No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that an order is, or is not, made under this section.

Section.MarginalNote: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability

Subsection.Text: Despite section 650, in any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice shall, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness who is under the age of 18 years or who is able to communicate evidence but may have difficulty doing so by reason of a mental or physical disability, or on application of such a witness, order that the witness testify outside the court room or behind a screen or other device that would allow the witness not to see the accused, unless the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order would interfere with the proper administration of justice.

Despite section 650, in any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness, or on application of a witness, order that the witness testify outside the court room or behind a screen or other device that would allow the witness not to see the accused if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order would facilitate the giving of a full and candid account by the witness of the acts complained of or would otherwise be in the interest of the proper administration of justice.

An application referred to in subsection (1) or (2) may be made, during the proceedings, to the presiding judge or justice or, before the proceedings begin, to the judge or justice who will preside at the proceedings or, if that judge or justice has not been determined, to any judge or justice having jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place.
In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the age of the witness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the witness’ mental or physical disabilities, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of any relationship between the witness and the accused;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether the witness needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: whether the order is needed to protect the identity of a peace officer who has acted, is acting or will be acting in an undercover capacity, or of a person who has acted, is acting or will be acting covertly under the direction of a peace officer;

Paragraph.Label: (f.1)
Paragraph.Text: whether the order is needed to protect the witness’s identity if they have had, have or will have responsibilities relating to national security or intelligence;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

Subsection.Text: If the judge or justice is of the opinion that it is necessary for a witness to testify in order to determine whether an order under subsection (2) should be made in respect of that witness, the judge or justice shall order that the witness testify in accordance with that subsection.

A witness shall not testify outside the court room in accordance with an order made under subsection (1) or (2) unless arrangements are made for the accused, the judge or justice and the jury to watch the testimony of the witness by means of closed-circuit television or otherwise and the accused is permitted to communicate with counsel while watching the testimony.
No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that an order is, or is not, made under subsection (1) or (2).

Section.MarginalNote: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18

Subsection.Text: In any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice shall, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness who is under the age of 18 years, or on application of such a witness, order that the accused not personally cross-examine the witness, unless the judge or justice is of the opinion that the proper administration of justice requires the accused to personally conduct the cross-examination. If such an order is made, the judge or justice shall appoint counsel to conduct the cross-examination.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Accused not to cross-examine complainant — certain offences
Subsection.Text: In any proceedings against an accused in respect of an offence under any of sections 264, 271, 272 and 273, the judge or justice shall, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness who is a victim, or on application of such a witness, order that the accused not personally cross-examine the witness, unless the judge or justice is of the opinion that the proper administration of justice requires the accused to personally conduct the cross-examination. If such an order is made, the judge or justice shall appoint counsel to conduct the cross-examination.

In any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness who is not entitled to make an application under subsection (1) or (2), or on application of such a witness, order that the accused not personally cross-examine the witness if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order would allow the giving of a full and candid account from the witness of the acts complained of or would otherwise be in the interest of the proper administration of justice. If the order is made, the judge or justice shall appoint counsel to conduct the cross-examination.
In determining whether to make an order under subsection (3), the judge or justice shall consider

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the age of the witness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the witness’ mental or physical disabilities, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether the witness needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of any relationship between the witness and the accused;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

Subsection.Text: An application referred to in any of subsections (1) to (3) may be made during the proceedings to the presiding judge or justice or, before the proceedings begin, to the judge or justice who will preside at the proceedings or, if that judge or justice has not been determined, to any judge or justice having jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place.
No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that counsel is, or is not, appointed under this section.

In any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness, or on application of a witness, make an order directing that any information that could identify the witness not be disclosed in the course of the proceedings if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice.
The judge or justice may hold a hearing to determine whether the order should be made, and the hearing may be in private.
In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the right to a fair and public hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether the witness needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether the order is needed to protect the security of anyone known to the witness;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether the order is needed to protect the identity of a peace officer who has acted, is acting or will be acting in an undercover capacity, or of a person who has acted, is acting or will be acting covertly under the direction of a peace officer;

Paragraph.Label: (e.1)
Paragraph.Text: whether the order is needed to protect the witness’s identity if they have had, have or will have responsibilities relating to national security or intelligence;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the importance of the witness’ testimony to the case;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: whether effective alternatives to the making of the proposed order are available in the circumstances;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the salutary and deleterious effects of the proposed order; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

Subsection.Text: No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that an order is, or is not, made under this section.

Subject to subsection (2), the presiding judge or justice may make an order directing that any information that could identify the victim or a witness shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way, in proceedings in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any of the following offences:

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any offence under this Act, as it read from time to time before the day on which this subparagraph comes into force, if the conduct alleged would be an offence referred to in subparagraph (i) if it occurred on or after that day; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two or more offences being dealt with in the same proceeding, at least one of which is an offence referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: In proceedings in respect of the offences referred to in paragraph (1)(a) or (b), the presiding judge or justice shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the first reasonable opportunity, inform any witness under the age of eighteen years and the victim of the right to make an application for the order; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on application made by the victim, the prosecutor or any such witness, make the order.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2.2), in proceedings in respect of an offence other than an offence referred to in subsection (1), if the victim is under the age of 18 years, the presiding judge or justice may make an order directing that any information that could identify the victim shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way.
In proceedings in respect of an offence other than an offence referred to in subsection (1), if the victim is under the age of 18 years, the presiding judge or justice shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as feasible, inform the victim of their right to make an application for the order; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on application of the victim or the prosecutor, make the order.

Subsection.Text: In proceedings in respect of an offence under section 163.1, a judge or justice shall make an order directing that any information that could identify a witness who is under the age of eighteen years, or any person who is the subject of a representation, written material or a recording that constitutes child pornography within the meaning of that section, shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way.

An order made under this section does not apply in respect of the disclosure of information in the course of the administration of justice when it is not the purpose of the disclosure to make the information known in the community.

Section.MarginalNote: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses

Subsection.Text: Unless an order is made under section 486.4, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a victim or a witness, or on application of a victim or a witness, a judge or justice may make an order directing that any information that could identify the victim or witness shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice.

On application of the prosecutor in respect of a justice system participant who is involved in proceedings in respect of an offence referred to in subsection (2.1), or on application of such a justice system participant, a judge or justice may make an order directing that any information that could identify the justice system participant shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice.
The offences for the purposes of subsection (2) are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under section 423.1, 467.11, 467.111, 467.12 or 467.13, or a serious offence committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a terrorism offence;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under subsection 16(1) or (2), 17(1), 19(1), 20(1) or 22(1) of the Security of Information Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under subsection 21(1) or section 23 of the Security of Information Act that is committed in relation to an offence referred to in paragraph (c).

Subsection.Text: An order made under this section does not apply in respect of the disclosure of information in the course of the administration of justice if it is not the purpose of the disclosure to make the information known in the community.
An applicant for an order shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: apply in writing to the presiding judge or justice or, if the judge or justice has not been determined, to a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide notice of the application to the prosecutor, the accused and any other person affected by the order that the judge or justice specifies.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for an order shall set out the grounds on which the applicant relies to establish that the order is necessary for the proper administration of justice.
The judge or justice may hold a hearing to determine whether an order should be made, and the hearing may be in private.
In determining whether to make an order, the judge or justice shall consider

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the right to a fair and public hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether there is a real and substantial risk that the victim, witness or justice system participant would suffer harm if their identity were disclosed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether the victim, witness or justice system participant needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims, witnesses and justice system participants in the criminal justice process;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether effective alternatives are available to protect the identity of the victim, witness or justice system participant;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the salutary and deleterious effects of the proposed order;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the impact of the proposed order on the freedom of expression of those affected by it; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

Subsection.Text: An order may be subject to any conditions that the judge or justice thinks fit.
Unless the judge or justice refuses to make an order, no person shall publish in any document or broadcast or transmit in any way

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the contents of an application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any evidence taken, information given or submissions made at a hearing under subsection (6); or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other information that could identify the person to whom the application relates as a victim, witness or justice system participant in the proceedings.

Subsection.Text: Every person who fails to comply with an order made under subsection 486.4(1), (2) or (3) or 486.5(1) or (2) is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

For greater certainty, an order referred to in subsection (1) applies to prohibit, in relation to proceedings taken against any person who fails to comply with the order, the publication in any document or the broadcasting or transmission in any way of information that could identify a victim, witness or justice system participant whose identity is protected by the order.

In any proceedings against an accused, the presiding judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor or a witness or on his or her own motion, make any order, other than one that may be made under any of sections 486 to 486.5, if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order is necessary to protect the security of any witness and is otherwise in the interest of the proper administration of justice.

The application may be made, during the proceedings, to the presiding judge or justice or, before the proceedings begin, to the judge or justice who will preside at the proceedings or, if that judge or justice has not been determined, to any judge or justice having jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place.
In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the age of the witness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the witness’s mental or physical disabilities, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the right to a fair and public hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether the witness needs the order to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: whether the order is needed to protect the security of anyone known to the witness;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the importance of the witness’s testimony to the case;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: whether effective alternatives to the making of the proposed order are available in the circumstances;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the salutary and deleterious effects of the proposed order; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

Subsection.Text: No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that an order is, or is not, made under this section.
A justice who is satisfied by information on oath in Form 1 that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is in a building, receptacle or place

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: anything on or in respect of which any offence against this Act or any other Act of Parliament has been or is suspected to have been committed,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: anything that there are reasonable grounds to believe will afford evidence with respect to the commission of an offence, or will reveal the whereabouts of a person who is believed to have committed an offence, against this Act or any other Act of Parliament,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
