Section.MarginalNote: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis

Subsection.Text: A provincial court judge who on ex parte application made in Form 5.01 is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that a designated offence has been committed,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that a bodily substance has been found or obtained

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: at the place where the offence was committed,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on or within the body of the victim of the offence,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: on anything worn or carried by the victim at the time when the offence was committed, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: on or within the body of any person or thing or at any place associated with the commission of the offence,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that a person was a party to the offence, and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: that forensic DNA analysis of a bodily substance from the person will provide evidence about whether the bodily substance referred to in paragraph (b) was from that person

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and who is satisfied that it is in the best interests of the administration of justice to do so may issue a warrant in Form 5.02 authorizing the taking, from that person, for the purpose of forensic DNA analysis, of any number of samples of one or more bodily substances that is reasonably required for that purpose, by means of the investigative procedures described in subsection 487.06(1).

Subsection.Text: In considering whether to issue the warrant, the provincial court judge shall have regard to all relevant matters, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the designated offence and the circumstances of its commission; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether there is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a peace officer who is able, by virtue of training or experience, to take samples of bodily substances from the person, by means of the investigative procedures described in subsection 487.06(1), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: another person who is able, by virtue of training or experience, to take, under the direction of a peace officer, samples of bodily substances from the person, by means of those investigative procedures.

Subsection.Text: Where a peace officer believes that it would be impracticable to appear personally before a judge to make an application for a warrant under this section, a warrant may be issued under this section on an information submitted by telephone or other means of telecommunication and, for that purpose, section 487.1 applies, with such modifications as the circumstances require, to the warrant.

The court shall make an order in Form 5.03 authorizing the taking of the number of samples of bodily substances that is reasonably required for the purpose of forensic DNA analysis from a person who is convicted, discharged under section 730 or found guilty under the Youth Criminal Justice Act or the Young Offenders Act, of an offence committed at any time, including before June 30, 2000, if that offence is a primary designated offence within the meaning of paragraphs (a) and (c.02) of the definition primary designated offence in section 487.04 when the person is sentenced or discharged.

The court shall make such an order in Form 5.03 in relation to a person who is convicted, discharged under section 730 or found guilty under the Youth Criminal Justice Act or the Young Offenders Act, of an offence committed at any time, including before June 30, 2000, if that offence is a primary designated offence within the meaning of any of paragraphs (a.1) to (c.01) and (c.03) to (d) of the definition primary designated offence in section 487.04 when the person is sentenced or discharged. However, the court is not required to make the order if it is satisfied that the person has established that the impact of such an order on their privacy and security of the person would be grossly disproportionate to the public interest in the protection of society and the proper administration of justice, to be achieved through the early detection, arrest and conviction of offenders.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Order — persons found not criminally responsible and secondary designated offences
Subsection.Text: The court may, on application by the prosecutor and if it is satisfied that it is in the best interests of the administration of justice to do so, make such an order in Form 5.04 in relation to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is found not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder for an offence committed at any time, including before June 30, 2000, if that offence is a designated offence when the finding is made; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is convicted, discharged under section 730 or found guilty under the Youth Criminal Justice Act or the Young Offenders Act, of an offence committed at any time, including before June 30, 2000, if that offence is a secondary designated offence when the person is sentenced or discharged.

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: In deciding whether to make the order, the court shall consider the person’s criminal record, whether they were previously found not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder for a designated offence, the nature of the offence, the circumstances surrounding its commission and the impact such an order would have on the person’s privacy and security of the person and shall give reasons for its decision.

Subsection.Text: When the court makes an order authorizing the taking of samples of bodily substances, it may make an order in Form 5.041 to require the person to report at the place, day and time set out in the order and submit to the taking of the samples.

The court may make an order under section 487.051 authorizing the taking of samples of bodily substances when it imposes a sentence on a person, finds the person not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder or directs that they be discharged under section 730.
If the court does not consider the matter at that time, it

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall, within 90 days after the day on which it imposes the sentence, makes the finding or directs that the person be discharged, set a date for a hearing to do so;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: retains jurisdiction over the matter; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: may require the person to appear by closed-circuit television or any other means that allows the court and the person to engage in simultaneous visual and oral communication, as long as the person is given the opportunity to communicate privately with counsel if they are represented by counsel.

Section.Text: The offender or the prosecutor may appeal from a decision of the court under any of subsections 487.051(1) to (3).

Subsection.Text: A provincial court judge may, on ex parte application made in Form 5.05, authorize in Form 5.06 the taking, for the purpose of forensic DNA analysis, of any number of samples of bodily substances that is reasonably required for that purpose, by means of the investigative procedures described in subsection 487.06(1), from a person who, before June 30, 2000,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: had been declared a dangerous offender under Part XXIV;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: had been declared a dangerous offender or a dangerous sexual offender under Part XXI of the Criminal Code, being chapter C-34 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1970, as it read from time to time before January 1, 1988;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: had been convicted of murder;

Paragraph.Label: (c.1)
Paragraph.Text: had been convicted of attempted murder or conspiracy to commit murder or to cause another person to be murdered and, on the date of the application, is serving a sentence of imprisonment for that offence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: had been convicted of a sexual offence within the meaning of subsection (3) and, on the date of the application, is serving a sentence of imprisonment for that offence; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: had been convicted of manslaughter and, on the date of the application, is serving a sentence of imprisonment for that offence.

Subsection.Text: The application shall be accompanied by a certificate referred to in paragraph 667(1)(a) that establishes that the person is a person referred to in subsection (1). The certificate may be received in evidence without giving the notice referred to in subsection 667(4).
For the purposes of subsection (1), sexual offence means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under any of the following provisions, namely,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 151 (sexual interference),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 152 (invitation to sexual touching),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 153 (sexual exploitation),

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 155 (incest),

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 212(4) (offence in relation to juvenile prostitution),

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: section 271 (sexual assault),

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 272 (sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm), and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 273 (aggravated sexual assault);

Paragraph.Label: (a.1)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under subsection 348(1) if the indictable offence referred to in that subsection is a sexual offence within the meaning of paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under any of the following provisions of the Criminal Code, chapter C-34 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1970, as they read from time to time before January 4, 1983, namely,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 144 (rape),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 146 (sexual intercourse with female under fourteen or between fourteen and sixteen),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 148 (sexual intercourse with feeble-minded, etc.),

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 149 (indecent assault on female),

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: section 156 (indecent assault on male), or

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: section 157 (acts of gross indecency);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under paragraph 153(1)(a) (sexual intercourse with step-daughter, etc.) of the Criminal Code, chapter C-34 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1970, as it read from time to time before January 1, 1988; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an attempt to commit an offence referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (c).

Subsection.Text: The court may require a person who is given notice of an application under subsection (1) and who wishes to appear at the hearing to appear by closed-circuit television or any other means that allows the court and the person to engage in simultaneous visual and oral communication, as long as the person is given the opportunity to communicate privately with counsel if they are represented by counsel.

In deciding whether to grant an authorization under subsection (1), the court shall consider the person’s criminal record, the nature of the offence and the circumstances surrounding its commission and the impact such an authorization would have on the privacy and security of the person and shall give reasons for its decision.

If the court authorizes the taking of samples of bodily substances from a person who is on conditional release and who has appeared at the hearing, it shall make an order in Form 5.041 to require the person to report at the place, day and time set out in the order and submit to the taking of the samples.

However, if a person who is on conditional release has not appeared at the hearing, a summons in Form 5.061 setting out the information referred to in paragraphs 487.07(1)(b) to (d) shall be directed to them requiring them to report at the place, day and time set out in the summons and submit to the taking of the samples.

The summons shall be accompanied by a copy of the authorization referred to in subsection (1) and be served by a peace officer who shall either deliver it personally to the person to whom it is directed or, if that person cannot conveniently be found, leave it for the person at their latest or usual place of residence with any person found there who appears to be at least sixteen years of age.

If a person fails to appear at the place, day and time set out in an order made under subsection 487.051(4) or 487.055(3.11) or in a summons referred to in subsection 487.055(4) or 487.091(3), a justice of the peace may issue a warrant for their arrest in Form 5.062 to allow samples of bodily substances to be taken.
The warrant may be executed anywhere in Canada by a peace officer who has jurisdiction in that place or over the person. The warrant remains in force until it is executed.

Section.MarginalNote: Failure to comply with order or summons

Subsection.Text: Every person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with an order made under subsection 487.051(4) or 487.055(3.11) of this Act or under subsection 196.14(4) or 196.24(4) of the National Defence Act, or with a summons referred to in subsection 487.055(4) or 487.091(3) of this Act, is guilty of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than two years; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

Subsection.Text: For greater certainty, a lawful command that prevents a person from complying with an order or summons is a reasonable excuse if, at the time, the person is subject to the Code of Service Discipline within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the National Defence Act.
Samples of bodily substances shall be taken as authorized under section 487.051

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the place, day and time set out in an order made under subsection 487.051(4) or as soon as feasible afterwards; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, on the day on which the order authorizing the taking of the samples is made or as soon as feasible afterwards.

Subsection.Text: Samples of bodily substances shall be taken as authorized under section 487.055 or 487.091

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the place, day and time set out in an order made under subsection 487.055(3.11) or a summons referred to in subsection 487.055(4) or 487.091(3) or as soon as feasible afterwards; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, as soon as feasible after the authorization is granted.

Subsection.Text: If a person fails to appear as required by an order made under subsection 487.051(4) or 487.055(3.11) or a summons referred to in subsection 487.055(4) or 487.091(3), samples of bodily substances shall be taken

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when the person is arrested under a warrant issued under subsection 487.0551(1) or as soon as feasible afterwards; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as feasible after the person appears at the place set out in the order or summons if no warrant is issued.

Subsection.Text: Subsections (1) to (3) apply even if the order or authorization to take the samples of bodily substances is appealed.

A peace officer who is authorized under section 487.051, 487.055 or 487.091 to take samples of bodily substances may cause the samples to be taken in any place in Canada in which the person who is subject to the order or authorization is located.

The samples shall be taken by a peace officer who has jurisdiction over the person or in the place in which the samples are taken — or a person acting under their direction — who is able, by virtue of training or experience, to take them.

A peace officer who takes samples of bodily substances from a person or who causes a person who is not a peace officer to take samples under their direction shall, as soon as feasible after the samples are taken, make a written report in Form 5.07 and cause the report to be filed with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the provincial court judge who issued the warrant under section 487.05 or granted the authorization under section 487.055 or 487.091 or another judge of that provincial court; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the court that made the order under section 487.051.

Subsection.Text: The report shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the time and date the samples were taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the bodily substances that were taken.

Subsection.Text: A peace officer who takes the samples or causes the samples to be taken under their direction at the request of another peace officer shall send a copy of the report to the other peace officer unless that other peace officer had jurisdiction to take the samples.

Section.Text: No peace officer, and no person acting under a peace officer’s direction, incurs any criminal or civil liability for anything necessarily done with reasonable care and skill in the taking of samples of bodily substances from a person under a warrant issued under section 487.05, an order made under section 487.051 or an authorization granted under section 487.055 or 487.091.

Subsection.Text: A peace officer or a person acting under a peace officer’s direction is authorized by a warrant issued under section 487.05, an order made under section 487.051 or an authorization granted under section 487.055 or 487.091 to take samples of bodily substances by any of the following means:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the plucking of individual hairs from the person, including the root sheath;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the taking of buccal swabs by swabbing the lips, tongue and inside cheeks of the mouth to collect epithelial cells; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the taking of blood by pricking the skin surface with a sterile lancet.

Subsection.Text: The warrant, order or authorization shall include any terms and conditions that the provincial court judge or court, as the case may be, considers advisable to ensure that the taking of the samples authorized by the warrant, order or authorization is reasonable in the circumstances.

A peace officer who is authorized to take samples of bodily substances from a person by an order made under section 487.051 or an authorization granted under section 487.055 or 487.091, or a person acting under their direction, may take fingerprints from the person for the purpose of the DNA Identification Act.

Before taking samples of bodily substances from a person, or causing samples to be taken under their direction, in execution of a warrant issued under section 487.05 or an order made under section 487.051 or under an authorization granted under section 487.055 or 487.091, a peace officer shall inform the person of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the contents of the warrant, order or authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the investigative procedures by means of which the samples are to be taken;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the purpose of taking the samples;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the authority of the peace officer and any other person under the direction of the peace officer to use as much force as is necessary for the purpose of taking the samples; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of samples of bodily substances taken in execution of a warrant,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the possibility that the results of forensic DNA analysis may be used in evidence, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the sample is taken from a young person, the rights of the young person under subsection (4).

Subsection.Text: A person from whom samples of bodily substances are to be taken may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be detained for that purpose for a period that is reasonable in the circumstances; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be required to accompany a peace officer for that purpose.

Subsection.Text: A peace officer who takes samples of bodily substances from a person, or a person who takes such samples under the direction of a peace officer, shall ensure that the person’s privacy is respected in a manner that is reasonable in the circumstances.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Execution of warrant against young person
Subsection.Text: A young person against whom a warrant is executed has, in addition to any other rights arising from his or her detention under the warrant,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the right to a reasonable opportunity to consult with, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the right to have the warrant executed in the presence of

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: counsel and a parent or, in the absence of a parent, an adult relative or, in the absence of a parent and an adult relative, any other appropriate adult chosen by the young person.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Waiver of rights of young person
Subsection.Text: A young person may waive his or her rights under subsection (4) but any such waiver

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: must be recorded on audio tape or video tape or otherwise; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: must be made in writing and contain a statement signed by the young person that he or she has been informed of the right being waived.

Subsection.Text: Before taking samples of bodily substances from a person under an order made under section 487.051 or an authorization granted under section 487.055 or 487.091, a peace officer, or a person acting under their direction, shall verify whether the convicted offenders index of the national DNA data bank, established under the DNA Identification Act, contains the person’s DNA profile.

If the person’s DNA profile is in the convicted offenders index of the national DNA data bank, the peace officer or person acting under their direction shall not take any bodily substances from the person but shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: confirm in writing on the order or authorization that he or she has been advised that the person’s DNA profile is in the DNA data bank; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: transmit a copy of the order or authorization containing that confirmation and any other information prescribed by regulations made under the DNA Identification Act to the Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

Subsection.MarginalNote: DNA profile not in data bank
Subsection.Text: If the person’s DNA profile is not in the convicted offenders index of the national DNA data bank, the peace officer or person acting under their direction shall execute the order or authorization and transmit to the Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any bodily substances taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the order or authorization and any other information prescribed by regulations made under the DNA Identification Act.

Subsection.Text: No person shall use bodily substances that are taken in execution of a warrant under section 487.05 or under section 196.12 of the National Defence Act except to use them for the purpose of forensic DNA analysis in the course of an investigation of a designated offence.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Use of bodily substances — order, authorization
Subsection.Text: No person shall use bodily substances that are taken in execution of an order made under section 487.051 of this Act or section 196.14 of the National Defence Act, or under an authorization granted under section 487.055 or 487.091 of this Act or section 196.24 of the National Defence Act, except to transmit them to the Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police for the purpose of forensic DNA analysis in accordance with the DNA Identification Act.
No person shall use the results of forensic DNA analysis of bodily substances that are taken in execution of a warrant under section 487.05 or under section 196.12 of the National Defence Act except

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the course of an investigation of the designated offence or any other designated offence in respect of which a warrant was issued or a bodily substance was found in the circumstances described in paragraph 487.05(1)(b) or in paragraph 196.12(1)(b) of the National Defence Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any proceeding for such an offence.

Subsection.Text: Every person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.
Every person who contravenes subsection (1.1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction and liable to a fine not exceeding $2,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months, or to both.

Section.MarginalNote: Destruction of bodily substances, etc. — warrant

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), bodily substances that are taken from a person in execution of a warrant under section 487.05 and the results of forensic DNA analysis shall be destroyed or, in the case of results in electronic form, access to those results shall be permanently removed, without delay after

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the results of that analysis establish that the bodily substance referred to in paragraph 487.05(1)(b) was not from that person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person is finally acquitted of the designated offence and any other offence in respect of the same transaction; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the expiration of one year after

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the person is discharged after a preliminary inquiry into the designated offence or any other offence in respect of the same transaction,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the dismissal, for any reason other than acquittal, or the withdrawal of any information charging the person with the designated offence or any other offence in respect of the same transaction, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any proceeding against the person for the offence or any other offence in respect of the same transaction is stayed under section 579 or under that section as applied by section 572 or 795,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: unless during that year a new information is laid or an indictment is preferred charging the person with the designated offence or any other offence in respect of the same transaction or the proceeding is recommenced.

Subsection.Text: A provincial court judge may order that the bodily substances that are taken from a person and the results of forensic DNA analysis not be destroyed during any period that the provincial court judge considers appropriate if the provincial court judge is satisfied that the bodily substances or results might reasonably be required in an investigation or prosecution of the person for another designated offence or of another person for the designated offence or any other offence in respect of the same transaction.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Destruction of bodily substances, etc., voluntarily given
Subsection.Text: Bodily substances that are provided voluntarily by a person and the results of forensic DNA analysis shall be destroyed or, in the case of results in electronic form, access to those results shall be permanently removed, without delay after the results of that analysis establish that the bodily substance referred to in paragraph 487.05(1)(b) was not from that person.

A provincial court judge may, on ex parte application made in Form 5.08, authorize in Form 5.09 the taking from a person, for the purpose of forensic DNA analysis, of any number of additional samples of bodily substances that is reasonably required for that purpose, by means of the investigative procedures described in subsection 487.06(1), if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a DNA profile cannot be derived from the bodily substances that were taken from that person under an order made under section 487.051 or an authorization granted under section 487.055; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the information or bodily substances required by regulations made under the DNA Identification Act were not transmitted in accordance with the requirements of the regulations or were lost.

Subsection.Text: The application shall state the reasons why a DNA profile cannot be derived from the bodily substances or why the information or bodily substances were not transmitted in accordance with the regulations or were lost.

If the court authorizes the taking of samples of bodily substances from a person who is not in custody, a summons in Form 5.061 setting out the information referred to in paragraphs 487.07(1)(b) to (d) shall be directed to the person requiring them to report at the place, day and time set out in the summons and submit to the taking of the samples. Subsections 487.055(5) and (6) apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require.

On receipt of a notice from the Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police under subsection 5.2(1) of the DNA Identification Act that an order made under section 487.051 or an authorization granted under section 487.091 appears to be defective, the Attorney General shall review the order or authorization and the court record.
If the Attorney General is of the opinion that the defect is due to a clerical error, the Attorney General shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: apply, ex parte, to the judge who made the order or authorization, or to a judge of the same court, to have it corrected; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: transmit a copy of the corrected order or authorization, if any, to the Commissioner.

Subsection.Text: If the Attorney General is of the opinion that the offence referred to in the order or authorization is not a designated offence, the Attorney General shall inform the Commissioner of that opinion.

If the Attorney General is of the opinion that the offence referred to in the order or authorization is a designated offence, the Attorney General shall transmit that opinion, with written reasons, to the Commissioner.

A justice may issue a warrant in writing authorizing a peace officer to do any thing, or cause any thing to be done under the direction of the peace officer, described in the warrant in order to obtain any handprint, fingerprint, footprint, foot impression, teeth impression or other print or impression of the body or any part of the body in respect of a person if the justice is satisfied

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by information on oath in writing that there are reasonable grounds to believe that an offence against this or any other Act of Parliament has been committed and that information concerning the offence will be obtained by the print or impression; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that it is in the best interests of the administration of justice to issue the warrant.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Search or seizure to be reasonable
Subsection.Text: A warrant issued under subsection (1) shall contain such terms and conditions as the justice considers advisable to ensure that any search or seizure authorized by the warrant is reasonable in the circumstances.
Subsections 487(2) and (4) apply, with such modifications as the circumstances require, to a warrant issued under subsection (1).

Where a peace officer believes that it would be impracticable to appear personally before a justice to make an application for a warrant under this section, a warrant may be issued under this section on an information submitted by telephone or other means of telecommunication and, for that purpose, section 487.1 applies, with such modifications as the circumstances require, to the warrant.

Heading.TitleText: Other Provisions Respecting Search Warrants, Preservation Orders and Production Orders

Subsection.Text: Where a peace officer believes that an indictable offence has been committed and that it would be impracticable to appear personally before a justice to make application for a warrant in accordance with section 256 or 487, the peace officer may submit an information on oath by telephone or other means of telecommunication to a justice designated for the purpose by the chief judge of the provincial court having jurisdiction in the matter.

An information submitted by telephone or other means of telecommunication, other than a means of telecommunication that produces a writing, shall be on oath and shall be recorded verbatim by the justice, who shall, as soon as practicable, cause to be filed, with the clerk of the court for the territorial division in which the warrant is intended for execution, the record or a transcription of it, certified by the justice as to time, date and contents.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Information submitted by other means of telecommunication
Subsection.Text: The justice who receives an information submitted by a means of telecommunication that produces a writing shall, as soon as practicable, cause to be filed, with the clerk of the court for the territorial division in which the warrant is intended for execution, the information certified by the justice as to time and date of receipt.
For the purposes of subsection (2), an oath may be administered by telephone or other means of telecommunication.

A peace officer who uses a means of telecommunication referred to in subsection (2.1) may, instead of swearing an oath, make a statement in writing stating that all matters contained in the information are true to his or her knowledge and belief and such a statement is deemed to be a statement made under oath.
An information submitted by telephone or other means of telecommunication shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the circumstances that make it impracticable for the peace officer to appear personally before a justice;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the indictable offence alleged, the place or premises to be searched and the items alleged to be liable to seizure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the peace officer’s grounds for believing that items liable to seizure in respect of the offence alleged will be found in the place or premises to be searched; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a statement as to any prior application for a warrant under this section or any other search warrant, in respect of the same matter, of which the peace officer has knowledge.

Subsection.Text: A justice referred to in subsection (1) who is satisfied that an information submitted by telephone or other means of telecommunication

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is in respect of an indictable offence and conforms to the requirements of subsection (4),

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: discloses reasonable grounds for dispensing with an information presented personally and in writing, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: discloses reasonable grounds, in accordance with subsection 256(1) or paragraph 487(1)(a), (b) or (c), as the case may be, for the issuance of a warrant in respect of an indictable offence,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: may issue a warrant to a peace officer conferring the same authority respecting search and seizure as may be conferred by a warrant issued by a justice before whom the peace officer appears personally pursuant to subsection 256(1) or 487(1), as the case may be, and may require that the warrant be executed within such time period as the justice may order.

Subsection.Text: Where a justice issues a warrant by telephone or other means of telecommunication, other than a means of telecommunication that produces a writing,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the justice shall complete and sign the warrant in Form 5.1, noting on its face the time, date and place of issuance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the peace officer, on the direction of the justice, shall complete, in duplicate, a facsimile of the warrant in Form 5.1, noting on its face the name of the issuing justice and the time, date and place of issuance; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the justice shall, as soon as practicable after the warrant has been issued, cause the warrant to be filed with the clerk of the court for the territorial division in which the warrant is intended for execution.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Issuance of warrant where telecommunication produces writing
Subsection.Text: Where a justice issues a warrant by a means of telecommunication that produces a writing,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the justice shall complete and sign the warrant in Form 5.1, noting on its face the time, date and place of issuance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the justice shall transmit the warrant by the means of telecommunication to the peace officer who submitted the information and the copy of the warrant received by the peace officer is deemed to be a facsimile within the meaning of paragraph (6)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the peace officer shall procure another facsimile of the warrant; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the justice shall, as soon as practicable after the warrant has been issued, cause the warrant to be filed with the clerk of the court for the territorial division in which the warrant is intended for execution.

Subsection.Text: A peace officer who executes a warrant issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication, other than a warrant issued pursuant to subsection 256(1), shall, before entering the place or premises to be searched or as soon as practicable thereafter, give a facsimile of the warrant to any person present and ostensibly in control of the place or premises.

A peace officer who, in any unoccupied place or premises, executes a warrant issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication, other than a warrant issued pursuant to subsection 256(1), shall, on entering the place or premises or as soon as practicable thereafter, cause a facsimile of the warrant to be suitably affixed in a prominent place within the place or premises.

A peace officer to whom a warrant is issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication shall file a written report with the clerk of the court for the territorial division in which the warrant was intended for execution as soon as practicable but within a period not exceeding seven days after the warrant has been executed, which report shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the time and date the warrant was executed or, if the warrant was not executed, a statement of the reasons why it was not executed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the things, if any, that were seized pursuant to the warrant and the location where they are being held; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the things, if any, that were seized in addition to the things mentioned in the warrant and the location where they are being held, together with a statement of the peace officer’s grounds for believing that those additional things had been obtained by, or used in, the commission of an offence.

Subsection.Text: The clerk of the court shall, as soon as practicable, cause the report, together with the information and the warrant to which it pertains, to be brought before a justice to be dealt with, in respect of the things seized referred to in the report, in the same manner as if the things were seized pursuant to a warrant issued, on an information presented personally by a peace officer, by that justice or another justice for the same territorial division.

In any proceeding in which it is material for a court to be satisfied that a search or seizure was authorized by a warrant issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication, the absence of the information or warrant, signed by the justice and carrying on its face a notation of the time, date and place of issuance, is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, proof that the search or seizure was not authorized by a warrant issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication.
A duplicate or a facsimile of an information or a warrant has the same probative force as the original for the purposes of subsection (11).

Section.Text: A peace officer, or a public officer who has been appointed or designated to administer or enforce any federal or provincial law and whose duties include the enforcement of this or any other Act of Parliament, may, in the course of his or her duties, exercise any of the powers described in subsection 487(1) or 492.1(1) without a warrant if the conditions for obtaining a warrant exist but by reason of exigent circumstances it would be impracticable to obtain a warrant.

If a search warrant is issued under section 487 or 487.1 or a search is made under such a warrant, every one who publishes in any document, or broadcasts or transmits in any way, any information with respect to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the place searched or to be searched, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the identity of any person who is or appears to occupy or be in possession or control of that place or who is suspected of being involved in any offence in relation to which the warrant was issued,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: without the consent of every person referred to in paragraph (b) is, unless a charge has been laid in respect of any offence in relation to which the warrant was issued, guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

Subsection.Text: On application made at the time an application is made for a warrant under this or any other Act of Parliament, an order under any of sections 487.013 to 487.018 or an authorization under section 529 or 529.4, or at a later time, a justice, a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction or a judge of the Court of Quebec may make an order prohibiting access to, and the disclosure of, any information relating to the warrant, order or authorization on the ground that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the ends of justice would be subverted by the disclosure for one of the reasons referred to in subsection (2) or the information might be used for an improper purpose; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reason referred to in paragraph (a) outweighs in importance the access to the information.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraph (1)(a), an order may be made under subsection (1) on the ground that the ends of justice would be subverted by the disclosure

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if disclosure of the information would

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: compromise the identity of a confidential informant,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: compromise the nature and extent of an ongoing investigation,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: endanger a person engaged in particular intelligence-gathering techniques and thereby prejudice future investigations in which similar techniques would be used, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: prejudice the interests of an innocent person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for any other sufficient reason.

Subsection.Text: Where an order is made under subsection (1), all documents relating to the application shall, subject to any terms and conditions that the justice or judge considers desirable in the circumstances, including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, any term or condition concerning the duration of the prohibition, partial disclosure of a document, deletion of any information or the occurrence of a condition, be placed in a packet and sealed by the justice or judge immediately on determination of the application, and that packet shall be kept in the custody of the court in a place to which the public has no access or in any other place that the justice or judge may authorize and shall not be dealt with except in accordance with the terms and conditions specified in the order or as varied under subsection (4).

An application to terminate the order or vary any of its terms and conditions may be made to the justice or judge who made the order or a judge of the court before which any proceedings arising out of the investigation in relation to which the warrant or production order was obtained may be held.

Section.Text: A warrant issued under section 487 or 487.1 shall be executed by day, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the justice is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for it to be executed by night;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reasonable grounds are included in the information; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the warrant authorizes that it be executed by night.

Subsection.Text: In this section,

Definition.Text: custodian means a person in whose custody a package is placed pursuant to subsection (2);
document, for the purposes of this section, has the same meaning as in section 321;
judge means a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction of the province where the seizure was made;
lawyer means, in the Province of Quebec, an advocate, lawyer or notary and, in any other province, a barrister or solicitor;
officer means a peace officer or public officer.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Examination or seizure of certain documents where privilege claimed
Subsection.Text: Where an officer acting under the authority of this or any other Act of Parliament is about to examine, copy or seize a document in the possession of a lawyer who claims that a named client of his has a solicitor-client privilege in respect of that document, the officer shall, without examining or making copies of the document,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: seize the document and place it in a package and suitably seal and identify the package; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: place the package in the custody of the sheriff of the district or county in which the seizure was made or, if there is agreement in writing that a specified person act as custodian, in the custody of that person.

Subsection.Text: Where a document has been seized and placed in custody under subsection (2), the Attorney General or the client or the lawyer on behalf of the client, may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within fourteen days from the day the document was so placed in custody, apply, on two days notice of motion to all other persons entitled to make application, to a judge for an order

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: appointing a place and a day, not later than twenty-one days after the date of the order, for the determination of the question whether the document should be disclosed, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: requiring the custodian to produce the document to the judge at that time and place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: serve a copy of the order on all other persons entitled to make application and on the custodian within six days of the date on which it was made; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if he has proceeded as authorized by paragraph (b), apply, at the appointed time and place, for an order determining the question.

Subsection.Text: On an application under paragraph (3)(c), the judge

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: may, if the judge considers it necessary to determine the question whether the document should be disclosed, inspect the document;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the judge is of the opinion that it would materially assist him in deciding whether or not the document is privileged, may allow the Attorney General to inspect the document;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall allow the Attorney General and the person who objects to the disclosure of the document to make representations; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: shall determine the question summarily and,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if the judge is of the opinion that the document should not be disclosed, ensure that it is repackaged and resealed and order the custodian to deliver the document to the lawyer who claimed the solicitor-client privilege or to the client, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the judge is of the opinion that the document should be disclosed, order the custodian to deliver the document to the officer who seized the document or some other person designated by the Attorney General, subject to such restrictions or conditions as the judge deems appropriate,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: and shall, at the same time, deliver concise reasons for the determination in which the nature of the document is described without divulging the details thereof.

Subsection.Text: Where the judge determines pursuant to paragraph (4)(d) that a solicitor-client privilege exists in respect of a document, whether or not the judge has, pursuant to paragraph (4)(b), allowed the Attorney General to inspect the document, the document remains privileged and inadmissible as evidence unless the client consents to its admission in evidence or the privilege is otherwise lost.

Where a document has been seized and placed in custody under subsection (2) and a judge, on the application of the Attorney General, is satisfied that no application has been made under paragraph (3)(a) or that following such an application no further application has been made under paragraph (3)(c), the judge shall order the custodian to deliver the document to the officer who seized the document or to some other person designated by the Attorney General.

Where the judge to whom an application has been made under paragraph (3)(c) cannot act or continue to act under this section for any reason, subsequent applications under that paragraph may be made to another judge.
No officer shall examine, make copies of or seize any document without affording a reasonable opportunity for a claim of solicitor-client privilege to be made under subsection (2).

At any time while a document is in the custody of a custodian under this section, a judge may, on an ex parte application of a person claiming a solicitor-client privilege under this section, authorize that person to examine the document or make a copy of it in the presence of the custodian or the judge, but any such authorization shall contain provisions to ensure that the document is repackaged and that the package is resealed without alteration or damage.
An application under paragraph (3)(c) shall be heard in private.

This section does not apply in circumstances where a claim of solicitor-client privilege may be made under the Income Tax Act or under the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act.
Every person who executes a warrant may seize, in addition to the things mentioned in the warrant, any thing that the person believes on reasonable grounds

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has been obtained by the commission of an offence against this or any other Act of Parliament;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has been used in the commission of an offence against this or any other Act of Parliament; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: will afford evidence in respect of an offence against this or any other Act of Parliament.

Subsection.Text: Every peace officer, and every public officer who has been appointed or designated to administer or enforce any federal or provincial law and whose duties include the enforcement of this or any other Act of Parliament, who is lawfully present in a place pursuant to a warrant or otherwise in the execution of duties may, without a warrant, seize any thing that the officer believes on reasonable grounds

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has been obtained by the commission of an offence against this or any other Act of Parliament;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has been used in the commission of an offence against this or any other Act of Parliament; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: will afford evidence in respect of an offence against this or any other Act of Parliament.

Section.MarginalNote: Restitution of property or report by peace officer

Subsection.Text: Subject to this or any other Act of Parliament, where a peace officer has seized anything under a warrant issued under this Act or under section 487.11 or 489 or otherwise in the execution of duties under this or any other Act of Parliament, the peace officer shall, as soon as is practicable,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the peace officer is satisfied,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that there is no dispute as to who is lawfully entitled to possession of the thing seized, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: that the continued detention of the thing seized is not required for the purposes of any investigation or a preliminary inquiry, trial or other proceeding,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: return the thing seized, on being issued a receipt therefor, to the person lawfully entitled to its possession and report to the justice who issued the warrant or some other justice for the same territorial division or, if no warrant was issued, a justice having jurisdiction in respect of the matter, that he has done so; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the peace officer is not satisfied as described in subparagraphs (a)(i) and (ii),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: bring the thing seized before the justice referred to in paragraph (a), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: report to the justice that he has seized the thing and is detaining it or causing it to be detained

ContinuedParagraph.Text: to be dealt with by the justice in accordance with subsection 490(1).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Restitution of property or report by peace officer
Subsection.Text: Subject to this or any other Act of Parliament, where a person, other than a peace officer, has seized anything under a warrant issued under this Act or under section 487.11 or 489 or otherwise in the execution of duties under this or any other Act of Parliament, that person shall, as soon as is practicable,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: bring the thing seized before the justice who issued the warrant or some other justice for the same territorial division or, if no warrant was issued, before a justice having jurisdiction in respect of the matter, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: report to the justice referred to in paragraph (a) that he has seized the thing and is detaining it or causing it to be detained,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: to be dealt with by the justice in accordance with subsection 490(1).

Subsection.Text: A report to a justice under this section shall be in the form set out as Form 5.2 in Part XXVIII, varied to suit the case and shall include, in the case of a report in respect of a warrant issued by telephone or other means of telecommunication, the statements referred to in subsection 487.1(9).

Subject to this or any other Act of Parliament, where, pursuant to paragraph 489.1(1)(b) or subsection 489.1(2), anything that has been seized is brought before a justice or a report in respect of anything seized is made to a justice, the justice shall,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the lawful owner or person who is lawfully entitled to possession of the thing seized is known, order it to be returned to that owner or person, unless the prosecutor, or the peace officer or other person having custody of the thing seized, satisfies the justice that the detention of the thing seized is required for the purposes of any investigation or a preliminary inquiry, trial or other proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the prosecutor, or the peace officer or other person having custody of the thing seized, satisfies the justice that the thing seized should be detained for a reason set out in paragraph (a), detain the thing seized or order that it be detained, taking reasonable care to ensure that it is preserved until the conclusion of any investigation or until it is required to be produced for the purposes of a preliminary inquiry, trial or other proceeding.

Subsection.Text: Nothing shall be detained under the authority of paragraph (1)(b) for a period of more than three months after the day of the seizure, or any longer period that ends when an application made under paragraph (a) is decided, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a justice, on the making of a summary application to him after three clear days notice thereof to the person from whom the thing detained was seized, is satisfied that, having regard to the nature of the investigation, its further detention for a specified period is warranted and the justice so orders; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: proceedings are instituted in which the thing detained may be required.

Subsection.Text: More than one order for further detention may be made under paragraph (2)(a) but the cumulative period of detention shall not exceed one year from the day of the seizure, or any longer period that ends when an application made under paragraph (a) is decided, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction or a judge as defined in section 552, on the making of a summary application to him after three clear days notice thereof to the person from whom the thing detained was seized, is satisfied, having regard to the complex nature of the investigation, that the further detention of the thing seized is warranted for a specified period and subject to such other conditions as the judge considers just, and the judge so orders; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: proceedings are instituted in which the thing detained may be required.

Subsection.Text: A thing may be detained under paragraph (1)(b) for any period, whether or not an application for an order under subsection (2) or (3) is made, if the lawful owner or person who is lawfully entitled to possession of the thing seized consents in writing to its detention for that period.

Subsection.MarginalNote: When accused ordered to stand trial
Subsection.Text: When an accused has been ordered to stand trial, the justice shall forward anything detained pursuant to subsections (1) to (3) to the clerk of the court to which the accused has been ordered to stand trial to be detained by the clerk of the court and disposed of as the court directs.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Where continued detention no longer required
Subsection.Text: Where at any time before the expiration of the periods of detention provided for or ordered under subsections (1) to (3) in respect of anything seized, the prosecutor, or the peace officer or other person having custody of the thing seized, determines that the continued detention of the thing seized is no longer required for any purpose mentioned in subsection (1) or (4), the prosecutor, peace officer or other person shall apply to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction or a judge as defined in section 552, where a judge ordered its detention under subsection (3), or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a justice, in any other case,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: who shall, after affording the person from whom the thing was seized or the person who claims to be the lawful owner thereof or person entitled to its possession, if known, an opportunity to establish that he is lawfully entitled to the possession thereof, make an order in respect of the property under subsection (9).

Subsection.Text: Where the periods of detention provided for or ordered under subsections (1) to (3) in respect of anything seized have expired and proceedings have not been instituted in which the thing detained may be required, the prosecutor, peace officer or other person shall apply to a judge or justice referred to in paragraph (5)(a) or (b) in the circumstances set out in that paragraph, for an order in respect of the property under subsection (9) or (9.1).

A person from whom anything has been seized may, after the expiration of the periods of detention provided for or ordered under subsections (1) to (3) and on three clear days notice to the Attorney General, apply summarily to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction or a judge as defined in section 552, where a judge ordered the detention of the thing seized under subsection (3), or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a justice, in any other case,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: for an order under paragraph (9)(c) that the thing seized be returned to the applicant.

Subsection.Text: A judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction or a judge as defined in section 552, where a judge ordered the detention of the thing seized under subsection (3), or a justice, in any other case, may allow an application to be made under subsection (7) prior to the expiration of the periods referred to therein where he is satisfied that hardship will result unless the application is so allowed.
Subject to this or any other Act of Parliament, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a judge referred to in subsection (7), where a judge ordered the detention of anything seized under subsection (3), or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a justice, in any other case,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is satisfied that the periods of detention provided for or ordered under subsections (1) to (3) in respect of anything seized have expired and proceedings have not been instituted in which the thing detained may be required or, where those periods have not expired, that the continued detention of the thing seized will not be required for any purpose mentioned in subsection (1) or (4), he shall

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if possession of it by the person from whom it was seized is lawful, order it to be returned to that person, or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if possession of it by the person from whom it was seized is unlawful and the lawful owner or person who is lawfully entitled to its possession is known, order it to be returned to the lawful owner or to the person who is lawfully entitled to its possession,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and may, if possession of it by the person from whom it was seized is unlawful, or if it was seized when it was not in the possession of any person, and the lawful owner or person who is lawfully entitled to its possession is not known, order it to be forfeited to Her Majesty, to be disposed of as the Attorney General directs, or otherwise dealt with in accordance with the law.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsection (9), a judge or justice referred to in paragraph (9)(a) or (b) may, if the periods of detention provided for or ordered under subsections (1) to (3) in respect of a thing seized have expired but proceedings have not been instituted in which the thing may be required, order that the thing continue to be detained for such period as the judge or justice considers necessary if the judge or justice is satisfied

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the continued detention of the thing might reasonably be required for a purpose mentioned in subsection (1) or (4); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that it is in the interests of justice to do so.

Subsection.Text: Subject to this or any other Act of Parliament, a person, other than a person who may make an application under subsection (7), who claims to be the lawful owner or person lawfully entitled to possession of anything seized and brought before or reported to a justice under section 489.1 may, at any time, on three clear days notice to the Attorney General and the person from whom the thing was seized, apply summarily to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a judge referred to in subsection (7), where a judge ordered the detention of the thing seized under subsection (3), or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a justice, in any other case,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: for an order that the thing detained be returned to the applicant.

Subsection.Text: Subject to this or any other Act of Parliament, on an application under subsection (10), where a judge or justice is satisfied that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant is the lawful owner or lawfully entitled to possession of the thing seized, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the periods of detention provided for or ordered under subsections (1) to (3) in respect of the thing seized have expired and proceedings have not been instituted in which the thing detained may be required or, where such periods have not expired, that the continued detention of the thing seized will not be required for any purpose mentioned in subsection (1) or (4),

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the judge or justice shall order that

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the thing seized be returned to the applicant, or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: except as otherwise provided by law, where, pursuant to subsection (9), the thing seized was forfeited, sold or otherwise dealt with in such a manner that it cannot be returned to the applicant, the applicant be paid the proceeds of sale or the value of the thing seized.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding anything in this section, nothing shall be returned, forfeited or disposed of under this section pending any application made, or appeal taken, thereunder in respect of the thing or proceeding in which the right of seizure thereof is questioned or within thirty days after an order in respect of the thing is made under this section.

The Attorney General, the prosecutor or the peace officer or other person having custody of a document seized may, before bringing it before a justice or complying with an order that the document be returned, forfeited or otherwise dealt with under subsection (1), (9) or (11), make or cause to be made, and may retain, a copy of the document.

Every copy made under subsection (13) that is certified as a true copy by the Attorney General, the person who made the copy or the person in whose presence the copy was made is admissible in evidence and, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, has the same probative force as the original document would have if it had been proved in the ordinary way.

Where anything is detained pursuant to subsections (1) to (3.1), a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction, a judge as defined in section 552 or a provincial court judge may, on summary application on behalf of a person who has an interest in what is detained, after three clear days notice to the Attorney General, order that the person by or on whose behalf the application is made be permitted to examine anything so detained.

An order that is made under subsection (15) shall be made on such terms as appear to the judge to be necessary or desirable to ensure that anything in respect of which the order is made is safeguarded and preserved for any purpose for which it may subsequently be required.
A person who feels aggrieved by an order made under subsection (8), (9), (9.1) or (11) may appeal from the order

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to the court of appeal as defined in section 673 if the order was made by a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction, in which case sections 678 to 689 apply with any modifications that the circumstances require; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to the appeal court as defined in section 812 in any other case, in which case sections 813 to 828 apply with any modifications that the circumstances require.

Subsection.Text: Any person to whom three days notice must be given under paragraph (2)(a) or (3)(a) or subsection (7), (10) or (15) may agree that the application for which the notice is given be made before the expiration of the three days.

Section.Text: Where any thing seized pursuant to this Act is perishable or likely to depreciate rapidly, the person who seized the thing or any other person having custody of the thing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: may return it to its lawful owner or the person who is lawfully entitled to possession of it; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where, on ex parte application to a justice, the justice so authorizes, may

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: dispose of it and give the proceeds of disposition to the lawful owner of the thing seized, if the lawful owner was not a party to an offence in relation to the thing or, if the identity of that lawful owner cannot be reasonably ascertained, the proceeds of disposition are forfeited to Her Majesty, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: destroy it.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this section and in sections 490.012 to 490.032.

Definition.Text: crime of a sexual nature means a crime referred to in subsection 3(2) of the Sex Offender Information Registration Act.
database has the same meaning as in subsection 3(1) of the Sex Offender Information Registration Act.
designated offence means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under any of the following provisions:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 7(4.1) (offence in relation to sexual offences against children),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 151 (sexual interference),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 152 (invitation to sexual touching),

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 153 (sexual exploitation),

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: section 153.1 (sexual exploitation of person with disability),

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: section 155 (incest),

Subparagraph.Label: (vi.1)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 160(2) (compelling the commission of bestiality),

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 160(3) (bestiality in presence of or by a child),

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 163.1 (child pornography),

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: section 170 (parent or guardian procuring sexual activity),

Subparagraph.Label: (ix.1)
Subparagraph.Text: section 171.1 (making sexually explicit material available to child),

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: section 172.1 (luring a child),

Subparagraph.Label: (x.1)
Subparagraph.Text: section 172.2 (agreement or arrangement — sexual offence against child),

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 173(2) (exposure),

Subparagraph.Label: (xvi)
Subparagraph.Text: section 271 (sexual assault),

Subparagraph.Label: (xvii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 272 (sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm),

Subparagraph.Label: (xviii)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 273(2)(a) (aggravated sexual assault — use of a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm or any firearm in connection with criminal organization),

Subparagraph.Label: (xviii.1)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 273(2)(a.1) (aggravated sexual assault — use of a firearm),

Subparagraph.Label: (xix)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 273(2)(b) (aggravated sexual assault),

Subparagraph.Label: (xx)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 273.3(2) (removal of a child from Canada),

Subparagraph.Label: (xxi)
Subparagraph.Text: section 279.011 (trafficking — person under 18 years),

Subparagraph.Label: (xxii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 279.02(2) (material benefit — trafficking of person under 18 years),

Subparagraph.Label: (xxiii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 279.03(2) (withholding or destroying documents — trafficking of person under 18 years),

Subparagraph.Label: (xxiv)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 286.1(2) (obtaining sexual services for consideration from person under 18 years),

Subparagraph.Label: (xxv)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 286.2(2) (material benefit from sexual services provided by person under 18 years), and

Subparagraph.Label: (xxvi)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 286.3(2) (procuring — person under 18 years);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under any of the following provisions:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 162 (voyeurism),

Subparagraph.Label: (i.1)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 173(1) (indecent acts),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)

Subparagraph.Label: (iii.1)
Subparagraph.Text: section 231 (murder),

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 246(b) (overcoming resistance to commission of offence),

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: section 264 (criminal harassment),

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 279 (kidnapping),

Subparagraph.Label: (vii.1)
Subparagraph.Text: section 279.01 (trafficking in persons),

Subparagraph.Label: (vii.11)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 279.02(1) (material benefit — trafficking),

Subparagraph.Label: (vii.12)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 279.03(1) (withholding or destroying documents — trafficking),

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 280 (abduction of a person under age of sixteen),

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: section 281 (abduction of a person under age of fourteen),

Subparagraph.Label: (ix.1)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 286.1(1) (obtaining sexual services for consideration),

Subparagraph.Label: (ix.2)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 286.2(1) (material benefit from sexual services),

Subparagraph.Label: (ix.3)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 286.3(1) (procuring),

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 348(1)(d) (breaking and entering a dwelling house with intent to commit an indictable offence),

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 348(1)(d) (breaking and entering a dwelling house and committing an indictable offence),

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 348(1)(e) (breaking and entering a place other than a dwelling house with intent to commit an indictable offence), and

Subparagraph.Label: (xiii)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 348(1)(e) (breaking and entering a place other than a dwelling house and committing an indictable offence);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under any of the following provisions of the Criminal Code, chapter C-34 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1970, as they read from time to time before January 4, 1983:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 144 (rape),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 145 (attempt to commit rape),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 149 (indecent assault on female),

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 156 (indecent assault on male), and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 246(1) (assault with intent) if the intent is to commit an offence referred to in any of subparagraphs (i) to (iv);

Paragraph.Label: (c.1)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under any of the following provisions of the Criminal Code, chapter C-34 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1970, as enacted by section 19 of An Act to amend the Criminal Code in relation to sexual offences and other offences against the person and to amend certain other Acts in relation thereto or in consequence thereof, chapter 125 of the Statutes of Canada, 1980-81-82-83:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 246.1 (sexual assault),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 246.2 (sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm), and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under any of the following provisions of the Criminal Code, chapter C-34 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1970, as they read from time to time before January 1, 1988:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 146(1) (sexual intercourse with a female under age of fourteen),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 146(2) (sexual intercourse with a female between ages of fourteen and sixteen),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)

Subparagraph.Label: (v)

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: section 167 (householder permitting defilement);

Paragraph.Label: (d.1)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under any of the following provisions of this Act, as they read from time to time before the day on which this paragraph comes into force:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 212(1)(i) (stupefying or overpowering for the purpose of sexual intercourse),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 212(2) (living on the avails of prostitution of person under 18 years),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 212(2.1) (aggravated offence in relation to living on the avails of prostitution of person under 18 years), and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 212(4) (prostitution of person under 18 years);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an attempt or conspiracy to commit an offence referred to in any of paragraphs (a), (c), (c.1), (d) and (d.1); or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: an attempt or conspiracy to commit an offence referred to in paragraph (b).

Definition.Text: Ontario Act means Christopher’s Law (Sex Offender Registry), 2000, S.O. 2000, c. 1.
pardon means a conditional pardon granted under Her Majesty’s royal prerogative of mercy or under section 748 that has not been revoked.
record suspension means a record suspension, as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Criminal Records Act, that has not been revoked or ceased to have effect.
registration centre has the same meaning as in subsection 3(1) of the Sex Offender Information Registration Act.
Review Board means the Review Board established or designated for a province under subsection 672.38(1).

MarginalNote.DefinedTermEn: verdict of not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder

Definition.Text: verdict of not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder means a verdict of not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder within the meaning of subsection 672.1(1) or a finding of not responsible on account of mental disorder within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the National Defence Act, as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of this section and sections 490.012 to 490.032, a person who is convicted of, or found not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder for, a designated offence does not include a young person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Youth Criminal Justice Act unless they are given an adult sentence within the meaning of that subsection for the offence; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Young Offenders Act, chapter Y-1 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1985, unless they are convicted of the offence in ordinary court within the meaning of that subsection.

Heading.TitleText: Order to Comply with the Sex Offender Information Registration Act
